results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

results.description:
Welcome future dance-a-holics!! Come dance with us again THIS FRIDAY! If you want to learn to social dance and have a blast while doing it, please join me for a beginner west coast swing class from 8:30-9:15pm (Experienced with WCS? Join Marcus Schwarz for the Intermediate class at 8:30!). If you like it and feel like sticking around, there is a west coast social dance from 9:15-11pm.

You don't need a partner.

You don't need to have any previous dance experience.

You can have two left feet.

This is all about having a blast while learning something new that you can actually use in your real life!

WHAT IS WEST COAST SWING?

West Coast Swing (WCS) is a modern, partnered social dance done all over the world.

It is danced to a wide variety of music, including R&B, Rock, Blues, and Lyrical: exactly what’s on the radio today and at functions you attend!

It fits in small spaces like bars, crowded dance floors—even your living room.

You do not need a partner to get started.  Most people come by themselves or with friends.

Once you’re hooked, there are places to dance WCS every night of the week in the Boston area.

People of all ages dance WCS.
results.name: Beginner & Intermediate West Coast Swing Class & Social Dance!

venue.name: Gilliland Observatory of the Museum of Science Parking Garage

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course.

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM. 

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!
results.name: Comm Ave long run  8-15+ miles

results.description:
Please note the change of location. Let us *not* park your car in the Kickstand Cafe parking lot.  You can find free or metered street parking 1-2 blocks away from Arlington center intersection.  If you are taking the subway, this location is about 1 mile from Alewife T stop.

Note: route maps at the links below show Spy Pond as start/end. We will be starting/ending at Kickstand cafe instead, rest of the details are correct.

Full marathoners: 19 miles

http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/287236119


Half marathoners: 10.5 miles


http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/287247959

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. 
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

results.description:
Event Organizers: Lisa Robbins,[masked]; Paul-William Gagnon.

Sign-up Procedure


If you are interested in participating in this event, sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done hikes of comparable challenge within the past three months.

Please note: If we ask for your three most recent hikes, including when and where, and you only list one, or not when, etc., we will not consider the question answered.


=========================

Read this hike's entire description and make sure you answer all of the questions in the pop-up box that appears when you RSVP.  The questions might not show up if you register from a phone or tablet, so if you don't see them, you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared, you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you sign up.

=========================

What We're Doing

The Adams Slide Trail, which ascends Mt. Adams' southern flank from the Great Gulf, was left to grow wild more than 40 years ago, but its extremely steep, rugged path is still discernible to the determined. After hiking into the Great Gulf, we'll pathfind/bushwhack/scramble our way up this route, climbing approximately 2400' in 1.25 miles. (Note: This section is steeper than the Huntington Ravine Trail.) We'll take in the views from majestic Mt. Adams, and then descend via the Air Line to the Appalachia trailhead.

Stats


This is a strenuous, full-body workout, for experienced hikers who enjoy an adventure off the beaten path.

The stats per the White Mountain Guide Online, plus best available re: Adams slide:


Total distance: 10.6 miles 
Total elevation gain: 4700'

Trails en route: Great Gulf, Six Husbands, Buttress, Adams Slide, Air Line.

We could alter our plans because of fatigue, weather, and/or other conditions. There is no guarantee we will complete the entire event as described here.

No guests are permitted. No dogs are permitted, due to the terrain.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you expect us to constantly wait for you while you putter around.

What to Bring

Your usual three-season gear, including 2-3 liters of water, lunch, snacks, rain/wind protection, layers for cooler temps and headlamps (cuz you never know). Use this list to make sure you have what you need:

http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf **

**Exception to this list: No cotton.


IN ADDITION: This trail is overgrown, and we will find ourselves bushwhacking at times. Long pants and long sleeves are recommended. Stash a pair of light gloves you don't mind getting torn and a pair of safety glasses in your pack. If you bring hiking poles, make sure you have a way to attach them to your pack.

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment. Test and adjust it prior to the trip. 

Directions 

We'll meet in the parking lot at the Appalachia Trailhead, where we will spot cars.

According to Google Maps, the trailhead is 170 miles and 2 hours 45 minutes drive time from Boston. Please give yourself some wiggle room to get there on time.

For customizable driving directions:

https://www.google.com/maps/place/Appalachia+Parking+Lot,+Gorham+Hill+Rd,+Randolph,+NH+03593/@44.3715812,-71.2887812,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x4cb3f368a79167f5:0x424dd284704521c8

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.


Weather

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event. I'll post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.

Use the following links for summit weather forecasts:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.320339409000496&lon=-71.29090635799963#.VecafLxVhHw


http://www.mountwashington.org/weather/summit_forecast.php 

http://www.mountain-forecast.com/peaks/Mount-Adams-2


=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
MindEx 2015: Cutting-edge research on the brain and mind. 

Event link HERE. Register HERE. Free and open to the public. 

Saturday, September 12th, 8–5:30pm. 

Sanders Theatre, 45 Quincy Street, Cambridge

Meet leaders and pioneers in genomics, microbiomics, neuroscience, psychology, artificial intelligence, participatory research, citizen science, and open-access research. Learn how to use your own data to contribute to research around the world. Nearly 5000 people have joined our participant community, pledging their data to the PGP's public data ecosystem, making ours one of the most well-characterized and empowered cohorts in history. With every donated byte, the utility of our data library grows. 

Keynote speakers are George Church, pioneer in the fields of personal genomics and synthetic biology, NAS and NAE electee, and 2011 Franklin Bower Laureate … and … Martine Rothblatt, CEO of United Therapeutics pharma, and founder of Sirius satellite radio. 

Other speakers include: Preston Estep, George Church, Martine Rothblatt, Ed Boyden, Ron Kessler, David McRaney, Jordan Smoller, George Church, Jack Harris, Madeleine Price Ball, KT Pickard, Sasha Wait Zaranek, Rob Morris, Justine Debelius. 

Sponsor: Presented by the Mind First Foundation, and the Personal Genome Project at Harvard University. 

Contact: [masked]. 

For more info visit mindfirstfoundation.org.
results.name: MindEx 2015

results.description:
The Boston Fall Open 2015 is the third in a series of quarterly open tournaments. The first two tournaments were lots of fun, and we hope to make this just as successful! For this event, we are lucky enough to be playing at Google's lovely Cambridge facility.


Unlike most Go tournaments in the US which use a handicap system, games in the upper divisions of the Boston Open will be even. We expect one or two divisions for dan level, one division for 1-5 kyu players, and one handicap division for 6-15 kyu players. Cash prizes will be awarded in all divisions, with a top prize of $150.

Logistics:

Pregistration required! There is a limit for this tournament of 50 players.

Preregistration closes on Friday, September 11th at 9 PM (12 hours before tournament starts).

Please use Paypal to pay online: we are having trouble with Meetup payments at the moment, so please click here to pay. Once your payment has been processed we will mark you as "paid" in Meetup.

Fee: $20 (All proceeds will go towards prize money)

AGA Membership Required!

You must be a registered AGA member before the tournament begins! http://www.usgo.org/join-aga-today

If you need to become a member, there are three options:

1. Online regular membership ($30)
2. Online one-day membership ($10)
3. MGA promo new membership ($15) - mail-in form, requires a signature from me (Walther) or David Kahn. I'm happy to meet people at the Wed, Thurs, Sat meetups to sign. This option may take some time to process, so act now!

Location: Google Cambridge, 353 Main St, Cambridge MA.

Transportation: Google Cambridge is seconds from the Kendall T stop on the Red Line.

Parking: There is a (non-free) parking garage behind the building, accessible from Ames St. Fare info is available here. Note that the listed address (4 Cambridge Center) is misleading! Use "77 Ames St Cambridge MA" with your GPS.

Food: Google has a no outside food/drink policy. Please eat breakfast and lunch at one of the many lovely restaurants in the area.

Time:

Check-in time: 8:15 am - 8:45am

Tournament start: 9am

Lunch will be a 1.5 hr break.

Format:

• All Games are AGA rated

• 4 rounds, Swiss McMahon pairing

• AGA rules, 7.5 komi


• Time Settings: 30 minutes main time, 5 x 40s byo yomi (overtime)

• All games will be even, except for the 6-15 kyu division, which will be handicapped according to rank. All division boundaries are subject to adjustment on tournament day, though this will be done after consulting with players who might be affected.

results.description:
Permaculture FEAST Weekend Design Course
http://permaculturefeast.org/

September 12, 13
September 26, 27
October 10, 11
October 24, 25
November 14, 15
December 5, 6
December 12 (make up day in case of bad weather)

$1150 early price
$1350 after July 31
save $50 if you sign up a friend

What you get:

Payment plans can be arranged. Course fee includes full course materials and certification, coffee, tea, handouts, gigabytes of course reference materials (digital format), access to an extensive physical permaculture library, field trips, guest instructors. One Sunday lunch each weekend included.

Permaculture is a vision, design system, and global movement that draws on patterns and principles found in nature to meet human needs, while regenerating the natural world and creating abundance we can share. This weekend permaculture design course moves from principles and patterns to details in a supportive, respectful and collaborative atmosphere to promote rapid learning of whole systems design. The course is centered on experiential learning and hands-on skill building, including local field trips where we will see theory in action. It covers the internationally recognized 72-hour permaculture curriculum with an additional focus on social permaculture, community building and organizing. The course concludes with a design practicum, where participants will work in small groups to develop a design for the course client.

This course is structured in twelve weekend day sessions, allowing full-time workers, students and people with families more flexibility to participate. Successful completion of this course will earn participants an internationally recognized Permaculture Design Certificate.

Our graduates leave ready apply what they’ve learned in their backyards, businesses and communities!

Topics include:
Permaculture principles & ethics
Reading the Landscape & Understanding Natural Cycles
Urban Homesteading
Forest Gardening
Water Harvesting
Soil Regeneration
Creative Waste Cycling
Micro-livestock
Energy & Building Systems
Social Permaculture
Food Systems Planning
Cooperative Economics
Design for Climate Change
Community Building & Organizing
Aquaculture
Soil Regeneration & Land Restoration
Design Projects, Methods, & Tools
results.name: Permaculture FEAST Design Course (PDC)

results.description:
A remarkable teaching, the Wholeness Process, will be available in the Boston area this September.  NLP trainer, researcher and author Connirae Andreas, PhD. has combined her skills in modeling human experience with her spiritual curiosity.   Through her own exploration and modeling of central spiritual teachings about Self realization, Connirae has built a bridge beyond our limiting perspectives.  This bridge allows grace and ease to flow into our lives, regardless of whether we are spiritually oriented.  Our awareness of freedom expands, while obstacles fade.


Connirae’s best selling NLP books Core Transformation and Heart of the Mind have helped thousands discover access to their deep inner resources. The Wholeness Process awakens a profound awareness of our wholeness and the grace that accompanies that knowing.


I know Connirae from 35 years ago when I was living in Boulder CO.  Seeing her artistry develop over the years, I was eager to take her training at Kripalu this April.  My expectations were met, and I continue to experience more freedom and ease in my life as I use the Wholeness Process.  This offering is doubly unique, in the presenter and training itself,  plus having it  brought to us right in the Boston area.

As a presenter, Connirae has her own gentle yet direct style, preparing us through her demonstrations to experience the process through the course exercises.  Through the demonstrations, practice, and carefully crafted participant manual, this exquisite process is introduced into our lives by a masterful trainer who embodies what she is teaching.


Please follow this link for the fascinating specifics and enrollment information from the organizer, MindBridge Trainings®.

http://www.mindbridgetraining.com/nlp-training/the-wholeness-process

Price: $395.00 Early Registration Discount until August 11  (This class is already over half filled so act promptly)

When you enroll on the MindBridge Trainings® site, please also RSVP here on the Meetup site to affirm our mutual journey in advance!
results.name: MindBridge Trainings: The Wholeness Process with Connirae Andreas

results.description:
Let's meet for a Saturday Morning Advanced-Beginner Bike Ride at Southfield in Weymouth!  We will be meeting and biking around the roads and off-roads of Southfield w/ members of the South Shore Hike Bike and Social Club (SSHBSC).  It's a great and relatively easy area to bike that we have returned this time for our 3rd Advanced-Beginner Bike Ride.  When we did this event in August we biked just over 11 miles in 1 hour and 5 minutes of biking time which was about 1 hour and 20 minutes total time if you include our stops to re-group.

 
We will bike 10-14 miles with a mix of mostly flat with some small hilly terrain in about 45-75 minutes. We will stop along the way every couple of miles or so. I do keep track of our mileage, time, etc. via an app on my phone.  (If you have an app to track as well please do so.)  Please bring your own bike.

 
Please Note:  

 1. Pace: As noted above, we will be biking 8-14 miles in about 1-1&1/4 hours so we will bike an average speed of 8-10 mph today. 
2. Please wear a helmet and review the rules of road. Please stay single file on the roads. Event Host/Organizer(s) are not responsible for any injuries or liabilities caused by participants.

3. This is weather-dependent. If the ground is too wet we will not bike.  I will post an update in the Conversations a few days prior to the event with a status update. 

**This event is being held in conjunction w/ South Shore Hike Bike & Social Club (SSHBSC) and Foxboro Grub and Grind (FGG).  If you are in more than 1 group please note I can give you attendance credit in both groups [after the event] but you will need to RSVP Yes for one of the larger groups and No for one of the smaller groups.  (Prefer Yes for SF and No in the others so I can easily find you in both groups as it's very challenging to find members in SF since it's so large.)**

Optional: We can grab a late breakfast or an early lunch at a nearby restaurant afterwards or have a potluck picnic and/or plan some future South Shore Social Fun events.  

 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Biking Levels (Rough Guide):

~Beginner-Friendly: Approximately 5-8 miles of relatively flat terrain biking an average speed of 5-10mph in 45 minutes time.  All levels welcome.

~Advanced Beginner: Either approximately 8-15 miles of mostly flat terrains with some small hills OR approximately 4-6 miles of mostly hills.  (Great for training and getting the heart rate up.)  The flatter longer terrain will have average speeds of 6-12mph biking in about 45 minutes to an hour.  The hillier shorter terrain will have varying average speeds probably closer to 3-4mph uphill and 15+mph (yikes!) downhill averaging 4-12mph.  Both will take about 45 minutes to 1 hr and 15 minutes.  All levels upward welcome.  (Beginner-Friendly bikers may be able to join us on some of these rides. Please check w/ the Event Host(s)/Organizer(s) before signing up to join this type of event.)

~Intermediate: Ride length of 12-25 miles with varying degrees of flat and hilly terrains.  We'll be biking about 8-15mph in about 1-1.5hours.

~Advanced: You can bike 20+ miles in about 1& 1/2-2 hours at an average speed of 12-20mph.

~Expert: You can do it all!!  This is a rare group of talented individuals.

***As always, safety first!  Please wear a helmet and review the rules of road.  Event Host/Organizer(s) are not responsible for any injuries or liabilities caused by participants.  Bike Rides are weather-dependent. If the ground is too wet we will not bike.  I will post an update in the Conversations a few days prior to the event with a status update.***

>>>This can also be found pinned on the Discussions tab.  Here is the direct link.  http://www.meetup.com/SocialFun/messages/boards/thread/48762263
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

South Shore Advanced Beginner Bike Ride #3

Saturday, September 12th @ 9:30am
Shea Field Naval Historical Aviation Museum Parking Lot Area @ Southfield

495 Shea Memorial Drive, Weymouth, MA

No Phone #.
Meeting Location: Meet in the parking lot between the Museum and Chapel.   Look for my bike and my Black Toyota RAV4.

Event Organizer/Host(s): Angela & Kirk ~~ We welcome another co-host!  This is a great event to co-host as most of the preliminary work (mostly scheduling) has already been done. ~~  Kit is our SSHBSC Event Co-Host. 

Min/Max: At least 6 Yes RSVPs 48 hours prior to the event (excluding Hosts and any of Hosts's Guests). Attendance is limited to 24 total people between all groups.   (The WL is set to Automatic, meaning as a spot opens up the next person on the WL will automatically be moved to the Yes list.  Please be sure to change your RSVP if you are no longer able to attend.)

Guests: 1 adult per member is welcome. 

Late Arrivals: We will start biking no later than 9:45am.  Please note we will circle back by the meeting location about 15-20 minutes (just over 4 miles) in so if you are running late be ready to bike with us by 10am; we will bike by within about 5 minutes of that time.

Cost/Fees:  There are currently no costs or fees associated with this event.  PMP does have some donation bins if you so wish to do so.  If you want to make your annual voluntary contribution to Social Fun I will be happy to collect and mail it to Biagio.

RSVP Deadline: Please finalize your RSVP by 6pm on Friday, September 11th to make sure you are on the printed RSVP list.  Any changes made after 8am on Saturday will be considered a No-Show.   The Event Organizer(s)/Host(s) reserves the right to cancel this event if we have less than 6 Yes RSVPs at the RSVP Deadline.

Inclement Weather: Any precipitation beyond "pop-up passing showers" or extreme heat will cancel but we will reschedule.  The Event Hosts will post an update 4-5 days prior to the event once have a viable forecast that can lead to proper decision-making.

Rain Date: TBD.  We will be hosting more Bike Rides in October and maybe November depending on the weather.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions: Best directions should be taken from mapquest.com or maps.google.com.


From Route 3: Take Exit18/Route 18SB: Follow approximately "2-3ish miles.  After you go straight thru the intersection with Marshalls and Whole Foods in the plaza on your left (get more info), at the next light (~1/4 mi), Southfield will be on your left.  Follow the road about 1/2 mile passing a plane and the Welcome Center on your right.  

Parking:  This parking lot can handle dozens of cars.  It's nestled between the old Chapel (which is next to a couple of soccer fields) and the Naval Historical Aviation Museum.

Note: All of my events are child-free and pet-free for adults 21+ only unless otherwise noted.  Thank you for being respectful of this request.

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the triangle between Magnolia and Thorndike Fields, just off the bike path.

results.description:
Harvest honey with us - from hive to jar! 

REGISTER ON THE BNC WEBSITE (http://ow.ly/RQR0S)

This two-hour family-friendly workshop will be led by Bill Perkins of Agricultural Hall and is a 100% participatory event, including a component in our Teaching Apiary where we will take off the harvestable frames of honey. Then we will extract the liquid gold inside using special equipment while we reflect on the honeybee’s year’s work, dip our fingers for a licking experience of our very own, and taste test various honeys. This workshop will cover the full cycle of extraction, including cleanup!

*If you would like to get up close when the beekeepers pull frames of honey from the hives you may wish to wear long pants and sleeves. Beekeepers, please bring veils; extra veils will be available for non-beekeepers. 


*FREE* for Mass Audubon members, all others $5 (Nonmembers can join today during checkout and take immediate advantage of member prices.)
results.how_to_find_us: http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/boston-nature-center/directions

results.description:
One of our members has graciously offered to host and skipper the boat for a harbor jaunt to the Isle of Shoals.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isles_of_Shoals

Mr. Bob J.  has offered his skipper services and the use of his boat at NO CHARGE to you.   He can carry up to eight additional passengers. 

It is a very, very kind offer. 

I hope you each find a way to thank him for his generosity. 

Be thoughtful, please RSVP only if you're certain you can attend. 

I've set the RSVP so that members must each RVSP for themselves. 

No guests this time. 

If you hit the wait list,  you are responsible to check Saturday morning to see if you've moved up on the list.   Host will not be monitoring that, nor alerting you.

UPDATE:  here are the answers you've been seeking for more details: 

 from Bob:

WHAT TO BRING: 

Tell them to bring a windbreaker, sneakers, food and drinks. 

WHERE TO MEET:  Meet on deck out back. 

AGENDA FOR THE DAY:   I will do what they want.  We will sail and take a launch ashore at the hotel and walk around.  back around 6.

results.description:
Looks like we are going to the museum!

If you have any interest in carpooling, please post a comment and we'll try to coordinate. 

Most likely I will park outside of the city and take the T in for save on parking and traffic headaches AND I feel like a local when I do!  The Orange Line from Orange Grove is very easy to get to and all are welcome to join me.  From Orange Grove into North Station, then the Green Line to Heath but get off on the MFA stop before a short walk to the Gardner.  Time to meet at Orange Grove TBD so that we can arrive at the entrance by 10:45.

Following the museum visit we will walk to an area restaurant for a bit to eat.

Discounts:

I'll be wearing my Red Sox hat to get $2 bucks off my admission!

Link to site:

http://www.gardnermuseum.org/visit

results.description:
FREE Laughter Yoga session at The Unitarian Church of Sharon, 4 North Main Street, from 11am to noon every second Saturday of the month. What a great way to start the weekend! Any age and any level of physical ability can participate in this uplifting experience! 

Enjoy this unique exercise of simulated laughter combined with gentle breathing that brings more oxygen to the body's cells. This oxygen boost gives enhanced vitality, energy and a feeling of real well-being.

Please bring your water bottle because laughing is dehydrating. Led by Certified Laughter Yoga Teachers, Linda and Bill Hamaker. www.letslaughtoday.com If you have any questions, just call them at[masked] or e-mail [masked]. PLEASE BRING A CANNED GOOD FOR THE SHARON FOOD PANTRY.

The front page of the March 15, 2013 Sharon Advocate (weekly newspaper) has this excellent article:  http://www.wickedlocal.com/sharon/features/x846070314/Yoga-laughter-a-lot-of-fun-in-Sharon?img=1#axzz2NcOfal37 and also this photo gallery on-line: http://www.wickedlocal.com/sharon/photos/x846070312/Photo-gallery-Laughter-yoga

venue.name: The Scandinavian Cultural Center in Newton

results.description:
This is the second year the Scandinavian Cultural Center arrange "Smörgåsbord Nordic Food Festival". Last year was a big success. There will be a lot of good food. 

You will need to get tickets for this event. General admission is $20 http://smorgasbord.bpt.me/

This year's theme is "The Battle"! Local chefs represent each of the five Nordic nations with dishes advised by local expat advisors and official cultural representatives. Loosely inspired by the Food Network's "Chopped," each chef serves a dish they have concocted which incorporates key ingredients from a Nordic nation's cuisine. Enjoy a taste of Norway, Denmark, Sweden, Finland and Iceland and vote for your favorite dish! Plus, tasting stations, Nordic vendors, and music and fun for all ages, including a kids' station and a Viking encampment, plus a live Viking battle reenactment after we crown the winning Nordic dish!

http://scandicenter.org/event/smorgasbord-nordic-food-festival-2/
results.name: SMÖRGÅSBORD NORDIC FOOD FESTIVAL

results.description:
What can get better than this?

Event Description
We have trucks coming from far and wide (New York to Maine!) just to be a part of this festival. So don’t miss it! We’ll have Vegan only food trucks as well as a few local favorites that will be ‘Vegan for the day’! Bring blankets and lawn chairs to picnic, enjoy live music, and free face painting for kids. Let’s celebrate Veganism the only way we know how…with food trucks!

Buy Your Tickets Here
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/vegan-food-truck-festival-tickets-15047648923

Meetup Details
We will meet at 11:30 at the fountain directly across from the Kendall subway stop. Promptly at 11:45 we will walk over to Broad Canal Way to the festival to get in line for the 12PM opening. We'll grab food from the trucks and find a place where we can sit and eat. I'll be posting our location to the meetup event page for anyone who is running late.

The festival will be held on broad canal way (the street that Charles River Canoe and Kayak is on).
results.name: Vegan Food Truck Festival

results.description:
Reportedly, this is the first time this many vegan food truck options are in one place! 

Come to Kendall Square to enjoy gourmet vegan cuisine from 10+ of this area's best vegan food trucks! 

A special VIP hour will take place from 11am-12noon. 
General admission will be from 12pm-5pm. There are only a limited number of tickets available for purchase, so be sure to buy your tickets online prior to the event to ensure you get in!

If we do not sell out of tickets prior to the event, there will be limited tickets available to purchase at the gate for $5 cash only. This will be on a FIRST COME, FIRST SERVE basis. Children under 12 are free! Food and drink purchased separately. ATMs will be on site. No refunds.

Check out VIP details and what trucks are participating at our website:

www.foodtruckfestivalsofamerica.com

Charles River Canoe and Kayak will be offering a 10% discount to any of our festival attendees the day of the festival. There's a port right at the festival on Broad Canal way!

https://www.facebook.com/events/1046093508753594/ 

https://scontent-lga1-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xft1/v/t1.0-9/11128183_845358978868801_3462462159610719524_n.jpg?oh=00a0e59004828d5479b41420933c7e85&oe=56746FFF

While many of these trucks coming to the festival are not vegan all the time, they have agreed to only serve vegan items on their menu. 
They worked with some activities to create a purely vegan event.

results.description:
It's that time of the year again. Oktoberfest and the Boylston Schul-Verein puts on a great one, Sat Sept 12th, Noon - 11 PM and Sept 13th, 1Noon - 6 PM.


This is a great family event, with lots of Music, Food, Children entertainment, and lots more...

results.description:
BOOK:

Sea of Poppies by Amitav Ghosh. This is the first of a trilogy.

22 copies in the Minuteman Library System.

DESCRIPTION:

A passion for history propels Ghosh's sweeping novels, in which love leaps the fences of race, caste, nationality, and class. After his complex tale of humankind's relationship with nature in The Hungry Tide (2005), Ghosh returns to the narrative grandeur of The Glass Palace (2001) in this lengthy yet fast-flowing historical novel about England's ruthlessly run opium industry in occupied India. It begins in a sea of poppies in Bengal, and culminates on board the Ibis, an old slave ship carrying a motley group of outcasts. There's brave Deeti, a young fugitive widow; dashing Zachary, the son of a former slave and her American master; adventurous Paulette, a French orphan; and Neel, a fallen raja. In vivid settings ranging from the hellish precincts of an enormous opium factory, to absurdly lavish upper-class households, to the Ibis' grim hold, Ghosh unfurls tales of betrayal and tyranny, revelation and transformation, while reveling in the mischievous inventiveness of a bawdy polyglot lingo favored by sailors on Eastern seas. With intimations of Dickens and Melville, Ghosh's vital saga encompasses suspense and satire, perverse cruelty and profound kindness, and the countless ways humans conceal desire and fear behind arrogance and brutality. More frolicsome language, penetrating insights, and high adventure will follow now that the Ibis trilogy is under way.

results.description:
(A set of 6 Saturday classes)

Rapier – The word evokes images of duels, high adventure, and swashbuckling. Have you had a desire to learn how these swords were used in combat during the Renaissance era? Much more than shouting “En Garde!” and assuming a guard stance; competent warriors fought with systems that included various ways to attack and defend, footwork, timing, and even rules of dueling, all based on a sophisticated understanding of body mechanics, mathematics and philosophy.

The 16th century was a period of change for the sword. No longer relegated to the battlefield; the sword changed as its wear became commonplace in society. Blades slimmed and guards became more elaborate as the sword evolved into a nimble thrusting weapon worn by commoner and noble alike. As a result, a number of fencing schools opened to capitalize on their growing popularity. The golden age of rapier study dawned around 1550; numerous masters publishing fencing system manuals over the century to follow, with topics including rapier, off-hand companions such as the dagger, buckler and cape, long sword, quarterstaff, pole arm, dagger alone, and grappling.

Our six-week Novice Rapier course will introduce the basic techniques and vocabulary of rapier fencing, enabling students to begin their study of period combat and the Art of Defence. The course will be taught by Charles and Robert, rapier scholars and Schole of Defence instructors.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

We invite you to come join the scholars and combatants of our Schole!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes [August 22, 29, and September 5, 12, 19 and, 26] and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  Class materials will be sent via email before the first session.)

Our workouts make will make you BETTER, not just tired, and our fitness familia will help you enjoy your time and ENCOURAGE you to give your best!


What to expect:

A challenging, motivating, and downright fun environment for training - perfect for after a long day of work.

TFW signature workout as seen on ESPN, The New York Times, and Boston Fitness Magazine, which has created world champions in multiple professional sports, and is individually-adapted for every person that takes part, even beginners!

Effective warm-ups to get you in the zone, and energetic intervals to invigorate mind and muscle.

Sweat, smiles, and lots of high-fives.


What NOT to expect:

Bootcamp instructors barking in your face.

Workouts that put exhaustion before results and safety.

Participants that are there just to feel like they’re better than someone else.


If you want to have fun and lose fat, gain strength, and improve your confidence and health, this is the place to be. Please bring water, workout clothes and shoes, a hand to high-five with, and a friend.

results.description:
This will be the last Saturday's Bread before they move to their new location. Will will not have this event for at least two months after September.

Interested in helping to feed the hungry? This is a great volunteer opporturnity for people who enjoy cooking. Its also a great event for meeting people.

After the event volunteers are encouraged to go to the Red Hat (located down the street) for a drink or bite to eat. Note that this is optional.

Event Summary:

12:30pm - 2:30pm Meal preparation & Dining hall
set-up
2:30pm - 3:30pm Meal is served by volunteers to guests
3:30pm - 4:30pm Clean-up

About Saturdays Bread:

Saturday’s/Sunday’s Bread is a program that serves free hot meals to people in need in Boston every Saturday and Sunday at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, 35 Bowdoin Street, Boston. Their mission is to provide healthy meals in a safe and inviting atmosphere, free from Society’s prejudices and judgments. This is an interfaith, interracial, interdenominational activity of people concerned with the hungry in the Boston area.

Over the course of its 25 years, Saturday’s/Sunday’s Bread has served more than 300,000 guests. Directions

Saturdays Bread is located at The Church of St. John the Evangelist is at 35 Bowdoin Street, Boston, between Cambridge Street and Derne Street behind the State House. The entrance to the dining hall is through the door to the right of the main church entrance. Go up the ramp and ring the bell marked "Clayton Hall," not "Church Business" or "Common Room." Please be patient; it sometimes is hard to hear the bell in the dining hall or kitchen.

Parking: Parking is a challenge, so it's a good idea to carpool or to go by T if possible. The on-street parking is very scarce. The closest public parking is the 100 Cambridge Street Parking Garage, which you enter from Somerset Street, one block east of Bowdoin. Parking at the garage is $7.00 for the full day on weekends.

There are a few other small parking lots nearby. The Boston Common Garage, a little further away, is $10 for the full day on weekends.

To reach the 100 Cambridge Street Parking Garage: Coming from Storrow Drive and West, go one block past Bowdoin Street (and past the 100 Cambridge Street building). Turn right at the next light onto Somerset. Coming from Government Center and South/East, turn left at the end of Center Plaza, the large, curved building opposite Government Center. The garage is on the right in the first block. If the auto entrance door is down, please knock; the garage is open Saturdays and Sundays.

Public Transportation: The closest T stop is the Government Center stop on the Green Line. From the subway exit, walk west on Cambridge Street two blocks and turn left on Bowdoin. The walk from the Park Street (Red/Green Line) station is a little longer, but a pleasant walk in good weather. Follow Park Street toward the State House, turn right on Beacon, then quickly left onto Bowdoin.

results.description:
Hale Reservation is a private, non-profit educational organization that manages 1,137 acres of woodlands, including four ponds and over twenty miles of trails in Westwood and Dover, Massachusetts.  http://halereservation.org/home/directions


We will hike around 4 miles over a couple of different trails. You will need either hiking shoes or sneakers. Bring water and snacks. 

Afterwards, we will grab a bite at Joe's American Bar and Grill - 985 Washington Highway, Dedham.

Please Read The Fine Print: 


Duration: Approximately 2 hours for the hike. However, any time estimate given is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time. There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there, then please don't sign up.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain, snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots or sneakers, bug spray, snacks and any personal medicines. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

No dogs are allowed on hikes. 

Please remember that I am a volunteer, the event is free, and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader you will be very disappointed. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

results.description:
Hi Urban Sketchers!  Continuing on with our neighborhood sketch series, let's sketch the South End!


The South End is a neighborhood of Boston, Massachusetts, it is bordered by the Back Bay, Chinatown, and Roxbury. It is distinguished from other neighborhoods by the Victorian style houses that can be found as well as the many parks that it holds within and around the area. The South End is the largest intact Victorian row house district in the country, which is made up of over 300 acres.  In this community you can find a series of eleven residential parks that are scattered around the South End. In 1973, the South End was listed in the National Register of Historic Places.  The beginning constructions of the South End started in 1849 with the neighborhood being built on tidal marshes.


We will meet at 2pm at the intersection of West Newton St. and Southwest Corridor Park (pictured above), and then disperse to sketch.  From this location there are a variety of subjects to sketch such as the Victorian row-houses on West Newton St., the Union United Methodist Church on Columbus Ave., the Boston skyline, or some of the foliage in Southwest Corridor Park.  We will reconvene at 4pm at the intersection of West Newton St. and Southwest Corridor Park to share our work and chat.


Looking forward to seeing you all!
results.how_to_find_us: Let's meet where West Newton St. intersects the Southwest Corridor Park. I'll be wearing a green backpack.
results.name: Let's Sketch! South End Neighborhood

We will hike around 4 miles over a couple of different trails. You will need either hiking shoes or sneakers. Bring water and snacks. 

Afterwards, we will grab a bite at Joe's American Bar and Grill - 985 Washington Highway, Dedham.

We will be joined by another meet up group.

Please Read The Fine Print:  


Duration: Approximately 2 hours for the hike. However, any time estimate given is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time. There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots, bug spray, snacks and any medicines you might need. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

No dogs are allowed on hikes.

results.description:
To truly know an algorithm isn't just to rattle off its big O running time - it's understanding how it interacts with real machines.

This session will begin with 15-minute interviews for each attendee (1 hour 15 minutes) with an individually-designed problem specifically on this topic. 

We'll spend 30 minutes on evaluations and areas of improvement. 

Afterwards, we'll take a short break and the remaining hour will be exercises dedicated to understanding how different sorts are used in different environments. We'll focus on the differences between merge sort and quick sort with different data sets (of varying sizes and characteristics) and how they interact with physical hardware.

What you'll get: personalized interview questions and feedback. Homework targeting your weak areas.

What you'll need: a laptop, power cord.
results.name: Theory in Practice: Sorts

results.description:
A member asked, and we have planned! Let's go trail horse back riding. I will need a head count at least a few weeks ahead of time to let them know how many plan to attend. The ride is an hour long. It costs $40 per person. They can't accommodate more than 13 so I am going to guess 10 would be a good number max. I have always wanted to do this. We may have to adjust the time a bit based on availability but let's plan for this afternoon.

Here's some info:

Q: What do you do on a Trail ride?A: Our guided western style trail rides are through a variety of trails, including  wooded areas, sand, over streams and around a pond. A trail ride is meant to be a relaxing ride on horseback to enjoy nature. You may even see a deer or two along the way.

Q: Is there an age requirement?A: Children must be 7 years or older and at least 48 inches tall.

Q: Is there a weight limit?A: Yes, we have a weight limit of no more than 250 pounds.  We reserve the right to refuse anyone whose size may threaten the health of our horses.

Q: What should I wear?A: You should wear comfortable weather appropriate clothing, long pants, sturdy footwear, sneakers are fine (no open toe shoes, flip flops or sandals). A limited number of helmets are available, you may use your own riding or bicycle helmet if you prefer. Helmets are not required but are always recommended.
You will be riding through wooded areas, so bug spray is always a good idea.

Q: I have never been on a horse before, can I still ride?A: Yes you can. We have many first time riders. Our Guides are experienced
riders and are there to assist you. Just follow the simple instructions that will
be given to you, and you should do just fine. If at any time during your ride you have a question, feel free to ask any of the Guides and they will be happy to assist you.

Q: What if my child is unable to control their horse?A: If any person is unsure about being able to control their horse, a guide can lead your horse from their horse.

Q: I have been riding for a while. Do you offer anything more advanced like
canter rides?A: Yes, We offer cantering rides for capable riders as judged by our guides.

Q: How do I know if I am ready for a more advanced ride?A: Our Guides will evaluate all riders who choose to take the more advanced
rides. If they feel you are unable to continue at that level, they will move you
down to a level that is better suited to your ability.

Q: Why do I have to ride single file?A: We ride single file to maintain safety of all our riders and horses.
results.how_to_find_us: Ask for Miah's group!
results.name: Go Horseback Riding!

results.description:
Beauty can be seen in all things, seeing and composing the beauty is what separates the snapshot from the photograph. – Matt Hardy

Join us as we explore the charming, historic, area of Boston known as Beacon Hill. We will focus on photographing the architectural details of this area packed with Federal, Greek Revival, and Victorian architectural treasures, antique shops and historic landmarks. This makes great practice for any traveling you may do where you want to capture the spirit of a place. What makes it unique? 

Three skills you will practice to help you take better pictures:

• See: What is your creative vision. Using composition and visual elements of color, texture and line to express the essence of what you see.

• Do: Do the right thing. Understand the fundamental camera settings necessary to realize your vision and make sure your photos are in clear focus and properly exposed.

• Be: Be present and connected to your surroundings so you can create photos from your personal experience. This makes the difference between a snapshot and a photograph. 

Come discover the architectural details of Beacon Hill in Boston hidden in plain sight. You can make the ordinary extraordinary through your photography.


We will visit the most exclusive neighborhood on the hill, Louisburg Square, and the African Meeting House, an important underground railroad destination for runaway slaves.


Learning to see creatively means slowing down to notice simple details right in front of you that have the potential to make a great photo. The things other people walk right by will suddenly jump out at you begging for your attention.

First, we will meet in front of Cafe Vanille and I will introduce you to some simple step by step practices for creative seeing so you can find beauty in the most unexpected places.

I have designed a series of  30 minute practices we will do together that will improve your composition, depth of field, and basic camera settings. Then you will have some time on your own to wander.


You will have a chance to try these out right away with my guidance.  You will receive individual coaching and critique while we are on the streets shooting. This way you can be confident that you will be able to repeat the process next time you are out on a shoot. This is a great session if you are interested in travel photography.

We will work with color, texture, pattern, and light to make our photos come to life. As always, this is a non technical jargon zone. It is all about the creative act of seeing and capturing the moments of life with a fresh eye.


I have found a fantastic area on Beacon Hill for our shoot. The winding streets are packed with interesting colors, reflections, architectural details, pipes, door knockers, all kinds of things you would never imagine would make great photo. 

Photo By former class participant Monica. T station base of Beacon Hill Old meets New.

I will share some simple tips for editing your photos to make them even more stunning.


This workshop is for you if:

• You own a camera (or smart phone with a camera) and you'd really like to use it more, but you're not really sure where to start and what to do.

• Maybe you've taken a photography workshop before or tried picking up one of those thick, boring books, but you quickly got overwhelmed and overloaded with the technical stuff.

• Your photos are “nice” but not jaw dropping all that often. You are not sure what to do to make them more dramatic and stunning.

Photo by class participant Lisa using reflections to capture fresh perspective

Any camera is fine for this shoot. You can even use your iPhone if you like. This is a fun, fast paced workshop. So if you would like to meet other people who love photography and are curious about how to take better photos, I hope you will join us.

The $30.00 tuition for the workshop is covered by my 100% SNAP HAPPY GUARANTEE.  If you are not happy with what you learn during the workshop, I will return your tuition to you on the spot.

We are going to have a great time! You have joined the group, now join the fun. RSVP right away to hold your space. I look forward to seeing you this Saturday from 3-6pm

Suzanne

P.S. After class we will end up in jail. The Liberty Hotel (former jail) is a great spot for refreshments after class. This is located at the base of Beacon Hill and is the perfect spot for us to take a look at the photos from the day.


More details will be provided once we have the full class participant list.

results.name: Travel Photography Beacon Hill: Architectural Details Fun Photo Workshop

results.description:
There will be a post film talk with Stanley Nelson, the director/filmmaker.

Film is 1 hour 56 minutes

Change was coming to America and the fault lines could no longer be ignored—cities were burning, Vietnam was exploding, and disputes raged over equality and civil rights. A new revolutionary culture was emerging and it sought to drastically transform the system. The Black Panther Party for Self-Defense would, for a short time, put itself at the vanguard of that change. The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution is the first feature length documentary to explore the Black Panther Party, its significance to the broader American culture, its cultural and political awakening for black people, and the painful lessons wrought when a movement derails. Master documentarian Stanley Nelson (Freedom Riders, Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple) goes straight to the source, weaving a treasure trove of rare archival footage with the voices of the people who were there: police, FBI informants, journalists, white supporters and detractors, and Black Panthers who remained loyal to the party and those who left it. Featuring Kathleen Cleaver, Elaine Brown, Emory Douglas, Jamal Joseph, and many others, it’s an essential history and a vibrant chronicle of this pivotal movement that birthed a new revolutionary culture in America.

Check out the trailer,

https://youtu.be/F56O3kZ9qr0

The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution
by filmmaker Stanley Nelson

I was 15 years old in 1966 when the Black Panthers were formed. The Panthers were talking about problems that had to do with our lives in the North, and as a New Yorker I was naturally attracted to them. Their look, their language, their boldness—it spoke to me.

At 20, I went to see The Murder of Fred Hampton, a documentary about the Chicago Police murder of a Panther leader. The film gave me even more insight into the Panthers, but it also made me look at the power of film to move audiences. It lit a fire inside of me to make films, and I’ve been on this path ever since.

Seven years ago, I finally set out to tell the story that had been in my mind all of those years. No one had documented the rise and fall of the Black Panther Party, and I wanted to shed light on a history that had never been told in its entirety. There is so much we think we know about the Party, but I wanted to go beyond the oversimplified narrative of the Panthers as prone to violence and consumed with anger, and explore why hundreds of young people joined, what they accomplished, and why it fell apart.

I also wanted to lift up the voices of rank and file members. We often hear about the leadership, but not unlike the foot soldiers of the Civil Rights Movement, the rank and file Party members were the lifeblood of the organization. They delivered Party newspapers, tested people for sickle cell anemia, registered voters, and fed thousands of children through their Free Breakfast programs. These were people in their teens and twenties who demonstrated an enormous amount of courage, discipline and organization. And despite their missteps and the FBI’s campaign to bring them down, what was so clear to me was that their motivation came from their undying love for their community.

Now, almost 50 years after the founding of the Panthers, we find ourselves at the start of a new movement for justice and equality led, yet again, by young people. We didn’t set out to make a film that was about today, but as we began shooting, it became painfully clear that so many things the Panthers were fighting for were things that are still issues today. From police brutality, substandard schools and substandard housing, to disenchantment with the political system.

I hope that young people come to see the film and reflect on the Black Panther Party, and consider the similarities—and differences—between what the Panthers tried to build, and the new movement that is taking shape today. I hope this history inspires young people, who may see their own desire for change reflected in the story of the Black Panther Party.

Ultimately, I wanted to bring this vibrant chapter in American history to life so that we can all understand it, learn from it, and make better decisions—personally and collectively.

results.description:
There will be a post film talk with Stanley Nelson, the director/filmmaker.

Film is 1 hour 56 minutes

Change was coming to America and the fault lines could no longer be ignored—cities were burning, Vietnam was exploding, and disputes raged over equality and civil rights. A new revolutionary culture was emerging and it sought to drastically transform the system. The Black Panther Party for Self-Defense would, for a short time, put itself at the vanguard of that change. The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution is the first feature length documentary to explore the Black Panther Party, its significance to the broader American culture, its cultural and political awakening for black people, and the painful lessons wrought when a movement derails. Master documentarian Stanley Nelson (Freedom Riders, Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple) goes straight to the source, weaving a treasure trove of rare archival footage with the voices of the people who were there: police, FBI informants, journalists, white supporters and detractors, and Black Panthers who remained loyal to the party and those who left it. Featuring Kathleen Cleaver, Elaine Brown, Emory Douglas, Jamal Joseph, and many others, it’s an essential history and a vibrant chronicle of this pivotal movement that birthed a new revolutionary culture in America.

Check out the trailer,

https://youtu.be/F56O3kZ9qr0

The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution
by filmmaker Stanley Nelson

I was 15 years old in 1966 when the Black Panthers were formed. The Panthers were talking about problems that had to do with our lives in the North, and as a New Yorker I was naturally attracted to them. Their look, their language, their boldness—it spoke to me.

At 20, I went to see The Murder of Fred Hampton, a documentary about the Chicago Police murder of a Panther leader. The film gave me even more insight into the Panthers, but it also made me look at the power of film to move audiences. It lit a fire inside of me to make films, and I’ve been on this path ever since.

Seven years ago, I finally set out to tell the story that had been in my mind all of those years. No one had documented the rise and fall of the Black Panther Party, and I wanted to shed light on a history that had never been told in its entirety. There is so much we think we know about the Party, but I wanted to go beyond the oversimplified narrative of the Panthers as prone to violence and consumed with anger, and explore why hundreds of young people joined, what they accomplished, and why it fell apart.

I also wanted to lift up the voices of rank and file members. We often hear about the leadership, but not unlike the foot soldiers of the Civil Rights Movement, the rank and file Party members were the lifeblood of the organization. They delivered Party newspapers, tested people for sickle cell anemia, registered voters, and fed thousands of children through their Free Breakfast programs. These were people in their teens and twenties who demonstrated an enormous amount of courage, discipline and organization. And despite their missteps and the FBI’s campaign to bring them down, what was so clear to me was that their motivation came from their undying love for their community.

Now, almost 50 years after the founding of the Panthers, we find ourselves at the start of a new movement for justice and equality led, yet again, by young people. We didn’t set out to make a film that was about today, but as we began shooting, it became painfully clear that so many things the Panthers were fighting for were things that are still issues today. From police brutality, substandard schools and substandard housing, to disenchantment with the political system.

I hope that young people come to see the film and reflect on the Black Panther Party, and consider the similarities—and differences—between what the Panthers tried to build, and the new movement that is taking shape today. I hope this history inspires young people, who may see their own desire for change reflected in the story of the Black Panther Party.

Ultimately, I wanted to bring this vibrant chapter in American history to life so that we can all understand it, learn from it, and make better decisions—personally and collectively.

results.name: THE BLACK PANTHERS: VANGUARD OF THE REVOLUTION Sat Sept 12th 7pm

We are still located in the beautiful studio of Yoga Mandala in Winchester, 750 Main Street, second floor.  There is on street parking AND a large parking lot. We will need to go shoeless once in the studio space (better for dancing too!) and put a yoga mat beneath our drums so as not to mark the beautiful floor. results.description:
Waterfire is a very unique art installation that Providence celebrates throughout the summer. It is perhaps one of the most challenging events to shoot at night due to the extreme contrast between bright-yellow/orange fires and black water background. The crowd of thousands of visitors doesn't make it easier and it is particularly difficult to get a good vantage spot for the lighting ceremony. Very rewarding, though, for those few cool shots.


Note that this event is self-directed, there is no formal group gathering, but I suggested a good starting point.


The lighting begins at 7:22, finding a place to shoot will take some time and so does parking. The Providence Place Mall garage is very cheap but also very popular for this event, it may be full unless you arrive early. I usually park in the streets or smaller lots 10 blocks away (where you will end up if you walk down the river).


Bring both a wide angle lens as well as a medium zoom for close-ups, no problem walking around with a tripod, but be careful not to trip anyone in the dense crowds. As you walk further down the river, the crowds spread out and it gets easier, especially half an hour after the lighting ceremony.


The official website has more details. Here is the link to a prior event.

The best meeting place is a small, circular plaza underneath the main road, see "How to find us" for exact coordinates (copy/paste them into Google maps). Just above, on Memorial Blvd, is the best place to view the parade, lighting ceremony and torch circle. From there, you can walk down the river to find lots of fires in the river, gondolas, street performers, glass blowers, living statues and gargoyles, art stands, food and more for a very diverse set of objects.
results.name: Waterfire Providence

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Please be sure to bring socks with you in order to play!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58

results.description:
Let's go to an awesome musical at M.I.T put together by the M.I.T and Wellesley students. They might be students but they are really good. I try to go every year.

The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee

Music & Lyrics by William Finn
Book by Rachel Sheinkin
Conceived by Rebecca Feldman Story:

An eclectic group of six mid-pubescents vie for the spelling championship of a lifetime. While candidly disclosing hilarious and touching stories from their home life, the tweens spell their way through a series of (potentially made-up) words hoping to never hear the soul-crushing, pout-inducing, life un-affirming "ding" of the bell that signals a spelling mistake. Six spellers enter; one speller leaves! At least the losers get a juice box. --MTI

Performances will be in
Kresge Little Theatre at M.I.T. Tickets are
$3 - Incoming MIT students
$6 - MIT and Wellesley students
$10 - MIT faculty, staff, and community; all other students; seniors and children
$15 - General public

Discounts available for groups of 10 or more people so RSVP on this site and text Erin K. at (978)[masked] if you plan on going so we get the group discount.

results.description:
NOTE: Season 5 will be led by  Senior Percolator, David Petringa.

HTML5 Brunch, our virtual self-study group focused on HTML5, CSS3 and responsive design, is returning for Season 5. This season will provide basic to intermediate training in HTML and CSS fundamentals. Season 5 targets beginner web designers, as well as, graphic designers, developers and programmers who want to get up to speed on these front-end technologies.

The format of a virtual self-study group is as follows:

• Each participant purchases the same textbook: HTML and CSS in 24 Hours, Sams Teach Yourself (Updated for HTML5 and CSS3) (9th Edition).

• Each participant commits to read two chapters per week (the chapters are short), complete the exercises and post links to your completed work.

• Each participant obtains assistance by posting questions to a discussion area set up on the Boston PHP Message Board for each chapter.  Each participant will receive personal feedback, as well as, a weekly group e-mail update.


• Each participant who completes the book is recognized on the Self-Study Group | Wall of Accomplishment.

Note: There is no classroom instruction. There are no webcasts. There are no scheduled appointments of any kind.

Once you have the book, you simply proceed at a pace that best fits into your current work/life schedule. You have the option to meet informally at the beginning of each Boston PHP Meetup, if you live in the Boston area. You DO NOT need to live in the Boston area to participate.  Invite your friends, family members and co-workers to join in the fun!


How do I get started?

• Become a member of Boston PHP if you are not already a member. Simply click: Join us!

• Register for HTML5 Brunch, Season 5.  Simply RSVP: Yes

• Purchase a book (the only program cost). Simply visit Amazon.com and order HTML and CSS in 24 Hours, Sams Teach Yourself (Updated for HTML5 and CSS3) (9th Edition) in one of two formats -- paperback or Kindle.


When your book arrives, start your virtual learning by reading one chapter at a time, completing the exercises and posting a link to your completed work.

FAQs:

Q: How long will the course last?

A: We will cover 24 chapters in the book starting Sunday, September 13 and ending Saturday, December 5.  Refer to the HTML5 Brunch, Season 5 -- Master Discussion List</a> for specific dates.

Q: Do I have to wait until Sunday, September 13 to begin?

A: No need to wait! Feel free to begin as soon as you obtain a copy of your book.  Simply post a message on the <a href="http://www.meetup.com/bostonphp/messages/boards/thread/49164866/">Introduction: HTML5 Brunch, Season 5 message board once you receive your book so that we can gauge participation. Then, proceed at a pace that best fits your current work/life schedule.

Q: Do I have to live in Boston to participate?

A: Not at all. This program is virtual. We have successful graduates from many states and even have graduates from countries in Europe and Africa.

Q: What if I have additional questions?

A: Simply post a reply below and you will receive a response.

Let's do Brunch!

Gene Babon
Chief Percolator

David Petringa
Senior Percolator
results.name: HTML5 Brunch, Season 5

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
This Week's Ride: Thirty First Annual Gryzboska Circle Ride (SWCCW)


10AM for 26, 39 or 56 miles on rolling terrain.

More details on the CRW Calendar: http://bit.ly/Iw67FE

Description:

he super short (SS) ride meanders southwest from Framingham to Ashland, Southborough and Hopkinton. The short (S) ride adds Upton. The long (L) ride adds Uxbridge, Mendon and Northbridge. All rides are rolling. The lunch stop for the short and long rides is in Upton center. The super short ride has no lunch stop. Most of the ride is on residential and rural roads with few traffic lights. Points of interest include Framingham Country Club, Charlie Chan's summer home, Whitehall Lake and State Park, scenic brooks, Upton State Forest, farms, llamas and the Ashland Town Forest. In nice weather this ride can attract over 70 riders. There may be autumn foliage to view. 

This is the arrow to follow for the ride:

This is a re-occuring ride every Sunday beginning in April, with the organized and marked rides of CRW (Charles River Wheelmen). The picture above is from one of last years rides. Don't let the # of RSVPs here fool you, these rides are always well atended usually with over 25 riders of all abilities.


The distances and routes vary every week. We'll have "No Drop Rule" so you won't have to worry about getting lost or keeping up. Ride with us if you ride anywhere from 15 to 20 MPH.

Always bring two spare tubes, and your preferred hydration and nutrition. We don't typically stop for lunch but depending on the ride, there are sometimes options to stop for a bit. Before riding it's good practice to get your bike tuned. Remember to dress for the elements.

Also CRW organizes a Spring Century, a Summer Century called Climb to the Clouds, and a Fall Century. All of the Centuries have organized food and water stops. I'm hoping to get a group committed to building up to these Century rides.

results.description:
Yoga not only increases strength and flexibility, but it is also a wonderful tool for healing. Yoga offers an opportunity to unwind and melt away the tension and stress that keep us locked up. As we practice yoga, old & restrictive patterns of movement are replaced by more dynamic and natural ways of moving, helping the body to heal itself.

A regular yoga practice brings life and energy to the body, improves overall circulation, and increases organ and gland functioning. As you stretch, the various systems of the body begin to have a greater capacity to function fully.

Slow Flow Alignment classes connect breath to movement through a dynamic sequence of yoga postures. Detailed alignment instructions are given to help students focus and get the most of their yoga practice. Ideal for those who are physically active or who have some previous yoga experience.

New students and drop-ins are always welcome! $15 per class or $125 for a 10-class card (can be shared/no expiration).

results.description:
Due to the last minute rescheduling of the New York trip I am offering a last minute fun session in the studio.n for just $30 you can have a while day of fun in the studio.



Not your average Lighting Workshop!  Bring your toys and come out to play! 

Forget lighting ratios and inverse square laws this is a session where we throw caution to the wind and get creative. Mixed lighting, fake windows, colored gels, moody and extreme portraits! It’s a time to have fun and experiment.  If enough people sign up quickly I will try to rustle up a model or two. 

Got your own lighting gear? want to know how to get creative with it? 

Then bring it along, whether it's Speedlights or studio lights Ian will show you how you can get really creative with it. 

It will take place  in the larger studio  Where else can you get to play in a fully equipped studio with professional help and instruction for such a low price?  Oh, and did I mention the fog machine!

The day will run from 10am am to 5pm with a break mid-way through for lunch. Lighting and equipment will be provided - or bring your own and get some instruction on how to use it. 

The  cost will be just $30  No experience is necessary,.
