results.description:
Indoor Rock Gym:  Central Rock Gym Watertown Ma (Monday's)

This Meetup is for weekly climbing at the Central Rock Gym in Watertown, MA. This meetup is intended to provide climbing partners for both lead and top rope climbers that sign up for the meetups.

Meet by the cubbies facing the Lead Wall (they will be on the right as you enter). I (Lovey) am usually wearing a teal harness with green & black climbing shoes.  Climb for 1.5 to 3 hrs. Adults of all skill levels and ages welcomed.  

**If you are leading, you should have your own rope. Work it out with your partner as to whose rope you'll be using if only one rope will be used between the two of you. Sometimes lead climbers prefer to lead on their own rope so both lead climbers may bring their own ropes to use. Word of caution: other climbers may help themselves to the second rope when it's not in use.


**If you come late, come find me or ask the CRG staff for help.  They know we climb on Mondays and can help you find the group. 

**There is another meetup group (and perhaps a second) that also climbs Watertown Mondays nights. If you miss the RSVP deadline, would appreciate a courtesy email/call to let me know you'll be joining us so I know to expect you.


**You are required to fill out the rock gym waivers. Go to their website http://www.centralrockgym.com/watertown.php and fill out their Liability Waiver online to save time when you arrive at the gym. 

**It is your responsibility to make sure you have taken the CRG Belay and/or Lead tests. If you have never climbed at CRG, you will be required to take their Belay test given by their staff only. Please make certain to come a bit early to allow for time to take their belay test.

**If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the "Intro Belay Class". You can sign up for this class (http://www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown under "Climbing Instruction).

**If you are interested in taking their Intro To Leading Climbing class, you can sign up for it at (http://www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown under "Climbing Instruction).

Equipment required: harness, shoes, chalk and belay device. 


Day Passes - $20 (Student/Military: $16)

10-Day Punch card $180 (Student/Military: $144)


Gear Rental:

- $8 Full Package

- $5 Harness

- $5 Shoes

- $2 Chalk

- $2 Belay Device

Membership options and further details are available on the website:http://www.centralrockgym.com/watertown.php

=============================================

Waiver:  Read !!!

Be Warned!

Mountaineering, Skiing – Alpine or Back Country, Rock & Ice Climbing by its very nature is an extremely hazardous activity.

Falling off any part of an climbing route or bouldering challenge or other associated activities, even hiking to a destination may result in injury or death. Weather, Trail conditions be it a slip on a trail or falling objects like rocks, climbing gear or tree’s from above, or avalanche can all incur injuries and/or death. 

Any information on this Meetup group page is for the basic understanding of what could be encountered. We do not guarantee any type of accuracy on this information. Seek your own additional resources of information.  You as an active member! Perhaps, lacking any of the following: professional training, good judgment, moral character or a conscience. We or anyone on any Meetup-Mountaineers cannot be held responsible in anyway.

When arriving at any Meetup you should always use your own best judgment. You must decide whether or not the conditions “ both physical or mental” are in your best interests. 

You cannot blame the organizer(s) if you get hurt. To join this meetup event you must acknowledge that you have read this waiver and thereby you completely and totally agree to indemnify the organizer(s) from any possible legal action related to any type of illness, injury, loss of equipment etc. that might potentially occur. We are not guides or leaders in any event held. Just the organizers of finding a meeting location that people with similar interests can meet and socialize.

That said have fun! Play safely! And take the responsibility of your own actions.


The Organizers…

results.description:
Mob Programming is a fairly new concept. From the outside it's a small team working together in one place at one computer. From the inside it's like having instant access to all the knowledge of all your teammates as you focus together on the code you're creating. It was started by development teams, not by consultants or academics.


Nancy Van Schooenderwoert will give a workshop for trying mob programming using a coding kata that the group will choose. We'll have a very brief intro to the mechanics of "mobbing" and then spend most of the time doing it. There'll be time to share observations, ask questions, and try variations.


Woody Zuill's team in California has been using mob programming for all their work since 2011 - purely because they want to. They get a lot more done, work normal hours, and spend just about all their time coding. Mob Programming has been spreading to teams in the UK, in Scandinavia, and right here in Boston.
results.name: Mob Programming Workshop

results.description:

But considering it's eight houses away, and pretty cool I'm posting this up. You can RSVP on their meetup here: http://www.meetup.com/NerdFunBoston/events/225087467/

Dr. Pamela Silver and her lab work at the interface between systems and synthetic biology to design and build biological systems in both mammalian and prokaryotic cells. They seek to both enhance our understanding of natural biological design, and to develop tools and concepts for designing cells, tissues and organisms. In the long term, they hope to develop principles for building synthetic cells that act as sensors, memory devices, bio-computers, producers of high value commodities and energy from the sun, and to build novel subsystems such as proteins with designed properties for therapeutic use. They seek to address ‘big’ unanswered questions that could have an impact on people and the world through engineered biological systems

Science by the Pint is sponsored by an organization of Harvard graduate students called Science in the News. In between their sleepless hours of hard work at Harvard Med School, they bring cutting edge scientific research to the public in a fun and informal format.
results.name: Science by the Pint: Pam Silver @Burren

From the Boston Doorknockers:

As we move into the fourth month of this project, we are kicking off a partnership with Boston Police Camera Action Team (BPCAT) to build support for their community-developed policy governing the implementation and use of body cams in Boston.

The policy is available here: http://www.bpcat.org/national-reports-and-studies/

The doorknocking project arises out of a national call for white folks to organize other white folks to support the struggle against police brutality and oppression of Black people in general.

This space is ideal for veteran activists and new comers alike! We'll update you on the status of the project, share our goals, and create lots of time to practice and get comfortable talking one on one about racism, white supremacy, and the work being in Boston.

We will be meeting in the library of the YWCA in Cambridge - use the Bishop Allen entrance if you are able to use stairs.

Use the Temple St entrance and call[masked] when you arrive if you need elevator access.

Children are welcome at all our events!

Contact us through posting, direct message, or [masked] if you have questions or specific needs.

This event is targeted at white allies, people of all races are welcome to participate.

results.description:
Welcome to our regular meetup!  We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing board games -- specifically, the kind of board games that make you think.  We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.


This season, in addition to playing games, we will be raffling off a bunch of popular games!  There will be a raffle at each meetup.  Simply by showing up, you'll get a chance to win free games. The more often you come, the more entries you'll receive.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message ahead of time, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm until the last people leave (usually quite a few hours).

Our group has been running since 2007, and at this point we have a pretty large crowd of regulars.  A lot of people come once every few weeks, and RSVPs are appreciated but not required, so the RSVP list is often smaller than our actual attendance.  We expect about 30-45 people at most of our meetups.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

People new to Euros are very welcome.  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); the heaviest strategy games (like 18xx or wargames); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Carcassonne.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (You will also receive extra raffle tickets any time you donate.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

results.description:
2 Player Games, ANY Game (Previously X-Wing Miniatures)

An opportunity to play those two player games that we do not play on a regular (mostly euro?) boardgaming night.  

If we have an odd number of players, or if we just feel like it, yes, it is fine doing a 3, 4 or 5 player game as well. 

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played? 


Anything.  Bring anything that you think will gather enough interest.  Examples: Netrunner, Marvel Dice Masters, Memoir '44, Twilight Struggle, Few Acres of Snow or even chess if that is your thing.  Put other suggestions on the event comments.

Will try this format a couple of times to see how it goes.

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q. What About X-Wing?
A. If you noticed, this spot is filling up the time previously scheduled for X-Wing Miniatures 100pts - so... as you may have guessed, Randy and I will be setting up a couple of x-wing miniatures tables for those of us inclined towards that game but still want to make the event more inclusive to other game genres (it is not often the wife allows me to invite my friends to play games, so I better make the best use of the time).

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are ladies night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from the cubbies if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the event Host(s) (see RSVP list) from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from cubbies if available).
results.name: MetroRock Monday

results.description:
We are brought together by our desire to serve and contribute to a more beautiful world, a healed world, a world built on the story of Interbeing. Because that story violates much of what we (as members of modern society) have been brought up to believe is normal, practical, responsible, and realistic, society exerts tremendous pressure to conform us to the old story -- the story of Separation.

As we envision and move toward a More Beautiful World, we are called to strengthen our energies; connect with our own center and with Source for guidance and wisdom; and deepen our connections and sense of community with each other. 

We'll work with a variety of relevant tools and practices including: qigong, centering meditation, and inner guidance partnering. 

Come, join in our deepening and community building.

To learn more about the larger movement:

results.description:
Sir:

You seem to advocate tolerance for the customary things discriminated against: race, color, creed, religion, etc. However, I do not believe you have ever made a reference to homosexuality (a perfectly legitimate psychological condition) without going specially out of your way to make a vicious insinuation, caustic remark, or “dirty dig.”

Your review of Truman Capote‘s Other Voices Other Rooms (TIME, Jan. 26) concludes . . . : “For all his novel’s gifted invention and imagery, the distasteful trappings of its homosexual theme overhang it like Spanish moss.”

I have seen a great deal of Spanish moss in a lot of places . . . and I must confess that some of it is quite beautiful. . . .

R. E. BERG

San Francisco, Calif.

Letter to the Editor of Time
results.name: Other Voices, Other Rooms - Capote

results.description:
Science and Cooking returns! - A semester-long public lecture series that pairs Harvard University professors with popular chefs and food experts to showcase the science behind different cooking techniques. This lecture series is sponsored by the Harvard University John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. 

Full Schedule below and HERE. Free and open to the public. 

:: :: ::

Lecture 2) Pasta Magic - Mark Ladner, (@ChefMarkLadner), Del Posto - Monday, Sept. 14

:: :: ::

These public lectures are based on the Harvard course “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” but do not replicate course content. Unless otherwise noted, all talks take place in the Harvard Science Center (1 Oxford St., Cambridge, Mass., Hall C) and begin at 7 p.m. Each presentation begins with a 15-minute lecture by a faculty member from the Harvard course, who will discuss one of the scientific topics from that week’s classSeating for all lectures is first come, first seated. If you have questions regarding this public lecture series, please contact [masked]. 

Sample Lecture: Explorations of Chocolate Textures [Lecture 4 (2012)]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tt9g2se1LcM&index=10&list=PL546CD09EA2399DAB


 Full schedule

Lecture 1) Monday, Sept. 7 - Thinking about Flavor - Dave Arnold (@CookingIssues), Booker & Dax, and host of “Cooking Issues” and Harold McGee (@Harold_McGee), writer, “Curious Cook”

Lecture 2) Monday, Sept. 14 - Pasta Magic - Mark Ladner, (@ChefMarkLadner), Del Posto

Lecture 3) Monday, Sept. 21 - The Science of Sugar - Joanne Chang ’91, (@jbchang), Flour Bakery, author of “Flour” and “Flour Too”

Lecture 4) Monday, Sept. 28 - Title TBA* - *Jim Lahey, (@jimlaheySSB), Sullivan Street Bakery

Lecture 5) Monday, Oct. 12 - Science and Emotions: Delicious or Disgusting? - Andoni Aduriz, (@mugaritz), Mugaritz and Ramon Perisé, Mugaritz

Lecture 6) Monday, Oct. 19 - Heat Transfer to Capture Flavors - Josep Roca, (@CanRocaCeller), El Celler de Can Roca and Raül Sillero, El Celler de Can Roca

Lecture 7) <Location TBA> Tuesday, Oct. 27 - Viscosity and Polymers - José Andrés, (@chefjoseandres), ThinkFoodGroup

Lecture 8) Monday, Nov. 2 - Title TBA - Bryan Voltaggio, (@BryanVoltaggio), Volt*Michael Voltaggio, (@MVoltaggio), Ink

Lecture 9) Monday, Nov. 16 - Fermentation on Wheels: Food Education and Community Impact - Tara Whitsitt, (@tarawhitsitt), Fermentation on Wheels

Lecture 10) Monday, Nov. 23 - Title TBA - Nathan Myhrvold, (@ModernCuisine), former Chief Technology Officer of Microsoft, co-founder of Intellectual Ventures, author of “Modernist Cuisine”

Lecture 11) Monday, Dec. 7 - Title TBA - Tom Colicchio, (@tomcolicchio), “Top Chef” judge and chef/owner, Craft Hospitality, and Mei Lin, (@meilin21), “Top Chef” season 12 winner, and Gail Simmons, (@gailsimmons), “Top Chef” judge, Culinary expert, and Food & Wine magazine Special Projects Director

The Harvard College Course: The Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS) and the Alícia Foundation developed a General Education science course, “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” which debuted in the fall of 2010. The course uses food and cooking to explicate fundamental principles in applied physics and engineering. (Watch a video about the course.) Limited to currently enrolled Harvard undergraduates, the class brings together eminent Harvard researchers and world-class chefs. 

:: :: ::

A version of “Science and Cooking” is offered for credit through the Harvard Extension School. An online course will be offered in the fall and spring semesters. Registered students will have access to the expertise and support of Harvard teaching staff.

:: :: ::

For more info visit <a>www.seas.harvard.edu.</a>

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
Join fellow LGBT folks for some informal bowling! The score isn't important - having fun and enjoying the company is! We usually have a wide range of abilities attend.

One of our semi-monthly bowls (the second and fourth Mondays of the month) - we'll be getting together at 7:30 at the Woburn Bowladrome in downtown Woburn (http://woburnbowl.com/index.htm).

The Woburn Bowladrome is located at 32 Montvale Avenue. They are just up the hill from Main Street and Route 38. You can get to the bowladrome from Route 93 by taking the Montvale Ave exit (Exit 36) or from Routes 128/95 from the Winn Street exit (exit 34). The bowladrome is near MBTA Bus 134 from Wellington Station. See below for more detailed directions/info. Parking is available in a large municipal lot behind the bowladrome and there's a back entrance to it from the lot. (The lot is the best place to park - there's little street parking nearby).

VERY IMPORTANT NOTE: Parking can be difficult! Please allow an extra 15 minutes to park, as you may need to wait for a space.


RSVP:

By 5:30, day of event. If you forget to RSVP, you can still come (and should!) - I can *almost* guarantee you'll get to bowl (so far they've always had extra lanes available when we've been going, but...?)


MEETING PLACE:

By 7:30 - Inside the Woburn Bowladrome. Look for us by the counter in the middle, between the two sets of lanes.


COSTS:

To be split among the group: The bowladrome charges $3.00 for shoe rental and $24 per hour ($12 per 1/2 hour) for bowling, with a $12 minimum (pricing is per lane). We've been averaging around $9-$11 per player lately, including shoes.

I am not currently asking for an event fee to cover Meetup's charges, but donations are welcome (max $1 a month). :) (I may take another look at this after the group's been running 6 months.)


DIRECTIONS:

If you're unfamiliar with downtown Woburn, I strongly recommend you print out a map of Woburn center before setting off, especially if you're following the directions from Route 128/95 North below. (There are a couple of quick moves you'll need to make around the common downtown.) A Google map is at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Main+St+@+Montvale+Ave/@42.4788298,-71.1425755,16z/data=!4m7!1m4!3m3!1s0x89e375abd656d707:0x2df321e83b3fdbdf!2s32+Montvale+Ave!3b1!3m1!1s0x89e375a96f6a0ad1:0x8eaf8f6e39ae9811

From Route 93 North: Get off at Exit 36 "Montvale Avenue, Woburn/Stoneham."

Turn left at the bottom of the ramp (towards Woburn).

Go approximately 1.6 miles - you'll see Walnut Street on the right and a dip in the road. Slow down and turn right at the Crest View Plaza building - the roadway leads to a municipal lot in back. There's a back entrance to the Bowladrome from the lot.

If you overshoot the right turn above, you'll pass the front of the bowladrome on your right - taking three rights around the block will lead you to Walnut St and the lot.

From Route 93 South: Get off at Exit 36 "Montvale Avenue, Woburn/Stoneham."

Turn right at the bottom of the ramp (towards Woburn).

Go approximately 1.6 miles - you'll see Walnut Street on the right and a dip in the road. Slow down and turn right at the Crest View Plaza building - the roadway leads to a municipal lot in back. There's a back entrance to the Bowladrome from the lot.

If you overshoot the right turn above, you'll pass the front of the bowladrome on your right - taking three rights around the block will lead you to Walnut St and the lot.

From Route 128/95 North: Get off at Exit 34 "Winn Street, Woburn/Burlington."

Turn right at the bottom of the ramp.

Follow Winn Street 1.7 miles until it ends at Woburn Common.

Take the required right turn - immediately get to the left and take the left around the common.

Immediately get into the middle lane and go straight through the traffic light (up the hill) - onto Montvale Ave.

The bowladrome will be on your left, followed by the Crest View Plaza building - there is a roadway just past them that will take you to a municipal lot for parking. The bowladrome has a back entrance from the lot.

MBTA Bus 134: Leaves the Wellington Station busway at 6:10, traveling through Medford and Winchester before getting to Woburn Square at approximately 6:45 (about 45 minutes early). A later bus leaves at 7:00, which gets to Woburn Square at approximately 7:35. If you take the later bus, be sure to send me a message so we can save you a space (see "your host" below). Note that I or someone else would have to give you a ride back - the last bus back inbound to Wellington leaves Woburn Square at 8:09.


YOUR HOST...

Will be Chris - the six foot tall guy with the beard (see pic). If you're running late or are lost, you can call or text me at  [masked] (Note this new cell number - and that every now and then it doesn't get coverage at my home.) My email is [masked].

Come create your own professionally crafted song using an iphone/ipad app and the guidance of a music professional, all while you socialize, collaborate, eat, and drink! Knowing how to play an instrument isn't necessary, only your love for music is.

MusicStudio is a new Boston start-up looking to be the next big social evening event. You'll be amazed at what you create!

The event will be hosted by Boston jazz musician & band leader Alex-Lee Clark. His band regularly plays at at The Beat Hotel, The Beehive, & Ryles Jazz Club, amongst others.


***Be sure to bring your iphone/ipad and headphones! At home before the event, make sure you install Garage Band and the loop package (see instructions below). Garage Band does not work on android devices.***

Download Instructions:
1. Download GarageBand onto your iphone/ipad.
2. Download the 'Select One' package for $5.99 at www.tuneuploops.com/tune-up-select.html & upzip the file onto your desktop.
3. Plug your device into your computer.
4. In iTunes, select your device and click on the 'Apps' tab.
5. Scroll to the bottom of the page to the 'File Sharing' section and select 'GarageBand'. Notice the list to the right is called 'GarageBand Documents’.
6. Drag and drop all instrument folders (Bass, Brass, Drums, etc.) from within your downloaded file into ‘GarageBand Documents’.
7. Press 'Apply' for your device to sync.


Please note there will be someone taking taking photos and/or videos for the meetup and group.

Sign-up for the Webinar at: https://www.innerengineering.com/online/free-meditation-webinars-2?signinsrc=Meetup-NewEngland

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email. 

(Technical Support:[masked]) 


Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.

These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful. 

You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on your own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

This free session will be facilitated by a trained Isha Kriya instructor. Contact: [masked],[masked] for more information about Isha USA or this session.

For more on Sadhguru and Isha, visit IshaUSA.org/blog

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Registration

ENET Member Rate – Free

General Public  – $10.00 (USD)

Please register at: http://enet.camp7.org/event-2005548/Registration

Pre-registration is preferred, however, walk-ins are always welcome.

Meeting Summary:

So you have started your own successful business and realize that you must grow to meet your customers’ needs. Or you are about obtain a large round of venture funding. In each case you need to rapidly scale your enterprise by increasing your workforce. These opportunities require different approaches to hiring. For the small boot-strapped organization, a gradual rate of growth may allow you to hire through professional and acquaintance networks. Web-based recruitment may also be useful. For the VC do-or-die rapid upscale, a skeleton management and technical team is likely in place. However, additional help from professional recruitment service providers or from the venture capitalist’s own internal recruiters is likely in order. And in any case, all of these hiring efforts must adhere to strict state and federal legal requirements.

On September 15th, Boston ENET will host speakers who will talk from their in-depth experience on these very topics. They will provide leads that you can rely on and point out approaches based on experiences that you can emulate. Come and join us to hear how it’s done and to network with eighty others who are facing the same challenges.

Panel:

Mitchell Sanders, Partner- CMC Consulting Group, USA, www.cmc-co.net

Mitchell Sanders, MS, PhD, has over 30 years of experie nce in preclinical animal models and clinical product development in advanced wound  care. With ECI Biotech, Mitchell has produced over 12 peer-reviewed publications and 24 worldwide patents in medical device and in vitro diagnostics. Mitchell is an expert in clinical and translational research and is a reviewer for the Wound Healing Society, CIMIT, MassVentures, MIT, WPI, Tech Sandbox, Piranha Pond, SBANE and the Venture Forum. Mitchell has an MS and PhD from WPI in molecular biology and biomedical sciences with 2 Postdocs (biochemistry and pathogen genetics) at the Whitehead Institute/MIT.


Jon Lane, Managing Partner, ProductWorks, Inc., www.productworksinc.com


Jon began ProductWorks, Inc. in 1998 after a 20 year career with Data General Corporation where he contributed to DG’s transition from an entrepreneurial company to a Global Fortune 500 enterprise. Promoted to Vice President, Corporate Human Resources in 1994, he had previously been responsible for Corporate Employment as well as Executive Leadership, Organizational Effectiveness and Talent Programs. Jon was interim Vice President of Human Resources at Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals supporting their growth from a 15 person start-up until just prior to their recent IPO. He also assisted the co-CEO’s of HiWired in growing their firm from 60 to 160 employees. Jon has a degree from Boston University and has taught in executive programs at Babson College, Columbia University and the University of Michigan.

Peter E. O’Neil, Professional Employer Consultant, Oasis Outsourceing, http://www.oasisadvantage.com

Peter E. O’Neil has been working in the start-up and small business community for more than 20 years. He has been self-employed and a small business owner. In addition, he has worked in several start up and new market divisions of companies including The Interface Group, Adecco HR Services, Administaff, TriNet and Robert Half where he has been recognized as one of the top contributors in the country.  Currently, Peter is a Professional Employer Consultant and works in Waltham for Oasis HR Outsourcing a nationwide provider of Fortune 500 employee benefits, payroll, Human Resources (HR) and compliance services to start-ups, small and growing companies. He is certified as an HR Generalist through the Society of Human Resource Management, (SHRM), and is licensed as an insurance broker in the Commonwealth of MA.  Peter has been a guest speaker for several entrepreneurial programs here in Massachusetts on topics including hiring, insurance, banking and HR issues. He is lifelong resident of MA.

Moderator:

Brigid Oliveri Siegel is Managing Partner and Founder of Brigid Siegel Associates, a retained executive search firm focused on high technology, biotechnology, clean tech, technology roles at universities, venture capital and private equity clients. Brigid’s  responsibilities encompass the execution and direction of a comprehensive search process from research strategy, candidate development, position and person specification through final candidate selection and offer. Brigid began her career in the high technology industry over 30 years ago and in executive search, 20 years ago. Prior to Brigid Siegel Associates  Brigid was a Partner at  Polachi, a Managing Director with The Onstott Group, a Senior Partner at Heidrick & Struggles and a Vice President with Fenwick Partners. She also founded and managed Brigid Siegel Associates LLC, a boutique retained executive search firm specializing in the high technology practice area. In addition to executive recruiting, her professional experience spans multiple positions in technology firms, including management, marketing, national account sales, software development and field engineering. Throughout her retained executive search career Brigid has successfully completed numerous information technology senior executive search assignments for clients ranging from emerging growth companies to multi-billion dollar corporations.

Brigid studied at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering from Lowell Technological Institute. Her executive search industry expertise has been cited in the Boston Business Journal, the New York Post, as well as Hunt Scanlon’s Executive Recruiting Industry Newswire. She was also a member of the Executive Board of the WPI (Worcester Polytechnic Institute) Venture Forum for seven years.

Thanks again for playing as we make our way forward.  I have faith this process will smooth out for future requests!


*****

As Beth did in the past, I will be curating the photography hung in the Oncology Wing at Baystate Franklin Medical Center and I am looking to this group to provide the photos. This is a great opportunity to have your work shown in a public setting!


As this is my first time setting this up, I made up the guidelines stated below and we can tweak them as we go.


I am looking forward to giving everyone a chance to participate in displaying their images and providing a welcome and much needed distraction to those visiting the Oncology wing!


*****

1. 15-20 images will be needed to fill the walls based on a print (matted print)  sized to 16" x 20"


2. Theme: "Fair, Fall, early Winter, Holiday."
(Sep-Dec time framed images)

3. Images can be recent or dust off a favorite from your image library.


4. Please upload 3ish images to this meet up for consideration.

5. Beth has generously donated 16"x20" frames for this use. You will need to provide a print or matted print with the final dimensions matching 16"x20"

6. If you prefer to provide framed photos, canvases, or metal prints these will be accepted as well.  But they must be "WIRED" and ready to hang.

13. The Image Title and Your Name need to be affixed to the back of your artwork.

Description: In this talk, Paul Brown will survey the DBMS field and provide guidance to pick data management technologies for different tasks


Speaker Bio: Paul Brown is currently the Chief Scientist at Paradigm4, working on SciDB. In the recent past, he has been a Senior Technology Staff Member at IBM’s Almaden Research Lab where he worked on (among other things) DB2, XML and JSON. Before that, he was an Architect at INFORMIX, working on database extensibility. Over this time-period, Paul has observed the rise and (typically) the fall of multiple DBMS technologies: SQL/relational, multi-value, object-oriented, document stores, XML, JSON, Hadoop, NoSQL, triple-stores, array DBMSs, and graph DBMSs.

results.description:
One of the greatest challenges to beekeeping in Massachusetts is getting colonies through the winter. Last year Eastern MA beekeepers lost over 50% of their colonies over the winter months; the bees (and beekeepers) need all the help they can get. Come learn from a panel of experienced local beekeepers the techniques they have used and found to be successful for overwintering. The panel will include Anita Deeley of Beverly Bees (& one of the state's Apiary Inspectors) and Mel Gadd of Clumsy Dog Apiary. These beekeepers have experience tending and overwintering Langstroth, Warre and Top Bar Hives. This session will be indoors and include guidance on how to prepare your hive for winter, with time for Q & A after the panel discussion.

Panelists: Anita Deeley (TBH & Langstroth) & Mel Gadd (Warre, TBH & Langstroth)

Directions: The building we will be meeting in is the Perry and Marty Granoff Music Center (Granoff for short); its address is 20 Talbot Ave, Medford, MA; we will be in Room 155. There is a visitor parking lot on the College Ave side of the building. The closest T stop is Davis (off the red line) and the 94 and 96 buses both stop across the street from the building (College Ave @ Dearborn).

Suggested Donation: $5
results.name: Preparing Your Hive for Winter (Metro North Session)

results.description:
SHERRY! 

FULL

Spanish Sherry, that is, from the Jerez de la Frontera region in the southern tip of Spain as the Mediterranean empties into the Atlantic. Land of Tapas, bordegas, the Solera wine aging system. REAL Spanish Sherry is a remarkable, somewhat under appreciated, fortified white wine that has been produced in the Jerez region since Phoenician times 3000+ years ago! It takes several forms, from bone dry to nutty to sweet.  

Please join me for a very special wine dinner at Taberna de Haro in Brookline featuring several types of Sherry and a tasting menu put together ESPECIALLY FOR US by the owner, chef and sommelier Deborah Hansen, a self-described Sherry fanatic. I have done a similar event with work colleagues and I can say without reservation that Deborah is the most knowledgeable Sherry and Spanish cuisine expert I have ever met.


COST

$50--$10 with RSVP

The event will cost $50 including tax and tip. I will take $10 with your RSVP and apply it to the bill at the end of the event. This will also hold your seat. The venue has requested that we pay in CASH to streamline the payment process, so come with $40 in cash.

Usual BostonWine refund policy applies. I will refund 100% up to 1 day in advance of the event. After that time, no refund. We are now using Meetup's payment service WePay. Let Jim know if there are any issues.

POLICIES

Limited to 20 total including +1s; final spots reserved for newbies. Everyone must be a member of BostonWine. RSVP early, but please don't RSVP unless you're sure that you can make it.

NOTE: As part of the RSVP process you will be asked to accept the group's Policies and Disclaimer (use a new web browser window to see the About Us section of our group's home page). You must answer "Yes" in this event's RSVP to attend. (Note, apparently some versions of the Meetup mobile app don't display this question -- in that case, RSVP with your phone and then use a web browser later on to update your RSVP). 

WHAT TO BRING

Just bring yourself (and $40)--the pairing will include food and Sherry.

MENU

BostonWine Meet Up
Sherry: Mysterious, Versatile, and Delicious!
at Taberna de Haro

Manzanilla Papirusa (by Emilio Lustau)
tortilla española ~ tall omelette of potato & onion
gildas ~ Andaluz tapa of olive, pickled pepper, white anchovy, caperberry

Fino Hidalgo (by Emilio Hidalgo)
Calamares fritos ~ fresh fried squid
Canapé de jamón serrano ~ cured Spanish ham on tomato toast

Amontillado AB (by Gonzalez Byass)
PImientos rojos asados con atún español y alcachofa ~ roasted red peppers with Spanish tuna and marinated artichoke

Oloroso Don Gonzalo (by Valdespino)
Pollo al ajillo ~ Chicken sautéed with garlic and brandy; salad

$50 per person (including tax and gratuity; cash only)

Tasting conducted by Chef-Owner-Sommelier Deborah Hansen,
Sherry Evangelist and Fanatic


WHERE


Taberna de Haro,
999 Beacon Street
Brookline, MA
www.tabernaboston.com

T Greenline C line, St. Mary's stop ** best
T Greenline D Riverside, Fenway *about 5 min walk

Parking: Beacon Street will have some parking, but remember BU is back in session, so parking spaces will be hard to come by. Landmark Center is 10 min walk, but near Fenway and costs $45 game days.

ABOUT

Taberna de Haro is one of the top Spanish restaurants in Boston and has a superb wine list, including many fantastic sherries. Fine Wine magazine as listed it in its 2015 Best Wine Lists in the World. 

I have organized a wine dinner here before for work and everyone was blown away by the sherry pairing. 

Look forward to seeing you there!

-jim

results.description:
Biotech Connection is hosting a free event on Sept 15: "Organs-on-chips: Revolutionizing the Drug Discovery Process"

The paradigm used by pharmaceutical companies to discover and develop new drugs is broken. Clinical studies take years to complete and testing a single compound can cost more than $2 million. Meanwhile, innumerable animal lives are lost, and the process often fails to predict human responses because traditional animal models do not accurately mimic human physiology. For these reasons, the pharmaceutical industry needs alternative ways to screen drug candidates in the laboratory. Microchips, called organs-on-chips, could one day form an accurate alternative to traditional animal testing. 

How is emulating human systems on microchips changing the drug development process?

Registration is FREE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/organs-on-chips-revolutionizing-the-drug-discovery-process-registration-17283423184

Program:

6:00 PM - Registration Begins
6:30 PM - Welcome and Opening Remarks
6:45 PM - Panel Discussion and Q&A
7:45 PM - Networking Reception

Speaker Bios:

Donald E. Ingber, MD, PhD
Professor, Harvard Medical School & Boston Children's Hospital

Dr. Donald E. Ingber is the Founding Director of the Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering at Harvard University, the Judah Folkman Professor of Vascular Biology at Harvard Medical School and Boston Children's Hospital, and Professor of Bioengineering at the John A. Paulson Harvard School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. His most recent innovation is a technology for building tiny, complex, three-dimensional models of living human organs, or "Organs on Chips", that mimic complicated human functions as a way to replace traditional animal-based methods for testing of drugs and establishment of human disease models. He was also the first to recognize that tensegrity architecture is a fundamental principle that governs how living cells are structured to respond biochemically to mechanical forces, and to demonstrate that integrin receptors mediate cellular mechanotransduction. Dr. Ingber has authored more than 375 publications and 85 patents, and has received numerous honors including the Holst Medal, Pritzker Award from the Biomedical Engineering Society, Rous-Whipple Award from the American Society for Investigative Pathology, Lifetime Achievement Award from the Society of In Vitro Biology, and the Department of Defense Breast Cancer Innovator Award.

Geraldine Hamilton, PhD
President and Chief Scientific Officer, Emulate

Geraldine A. Hamilton is the President and Chief Scientific Officer of Emulate. Prior to joining Emulate’s founding team, she served as Lead Senior Staff Scientist with the Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering at Harvard University. At the Wyss Institute, Hamilton led the Organs-on-Chips program and managed the multidisciplinary team responsible for developing, translating and commercializing the Organs-on-Chips technology. Hamilton’s career spans industry, academia, and the start-up world. Prior to her tenure at Harvard University, Hamilton spent more than 11 years in the pharmaceutical industry in leadership roles managing drug discovery teams. Her research achievements helped advance the development and application of human relevant in vitro models for drug discovery. Hamilton was a founding scientist and VP of Scientific Operations for CellzDirect, a start-up biotech company that specialized in providing cell products to the pharmaceutical industry for safety testing. Hamilton was responsible for the successful translation of CellzDirect’s technology from academia to broad use and acceptance across the industry. Hamilton received her Ph.D. in cell biology/toxicology from the University of Hertfordshire (England) in conjunction with GlaxoSmithkline, followed by a post-doctoral research fellowship at the University of North Carolina. She has authored more than 40 publications and numerous patents.

Peggy Guzzie-Peck, PhD
Global Head of Investigative Safety Sciences, Johnson & Johnson

Peggy J. Guzzie-Peck holds M.S. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Pittsburgh in Toxicology/Human Genetics with an emphasis on Genetic Toxicology. She has a distinguished track record of experience across diverse areas of toxicology, and has been a diplomate of the American Board of Toxicology since 1987. Peggy joined Johnson & Johnson in the Drug Safety Sciences Department in 2007, and served served as the Vice President and Global Head of Toxicology/Pathology and Laboratory Animal Medicine from 2008 to 2014. In her current role as Global Head of Investigative Safety Sciences, she led the Emulate collaboration for Janssen. In heading Investigative Safety Sciences, she chairs the Investigative Sciences & Strategy Council, serves as the Institutional Officer for animal welfare for US based animal facilities, participates in the Institutional Officer Consortia, is on the board for the Innovation and Quality in Pharmaceutical Development Consortia, and participates in the development of preclinical safety initiatives and strategies for new predictive safety testing. Peggy has held several management-level positions at Pfizer, Inc. including the head of Genetic Toxicology and Executive Director of Toxicology. She also managed Genetic Toxicology at G.D. Searle. Peggy has served on several international expert work groups in Preclinical Safety, Genetic Toxicology, In Vitro Toxicology, Photosafety and Safety Pharmacology.

Moderator:

John Carroll
Editor-in-Chief, FierceBiotech

John D. Carroll is a biotech analyst with 36 years of experience in journalism that’s taken him all over the world--and back again. Appointed editor of FierceBiotech in 2003, he has covered everything from city hall in Kansas City, KS, to biotech in London. He contributed stories from Central America and Ireland to the Dallas Morning News and Time and wrote for the Houston Press and a medley of other publications. He spent six years as editor and then publisher of the Dallas Business Journal, was publisher of Texas Business for a brief stint and early in his career was part of a big team of reporters and editors at the Kansas City Star & Times that investigated the deadly 1981 disaster at a local Hyatt Regency. The newspapers won a 1982 Pulitzer for their collective work. Carroll lives in Vermont and travels frequently.

Location:

Ray and Maria Stata Center, #32-123
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
32 Vassar Street
Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139
results.name: Organs-on-Chips: Revolutionizing the Drug Discovery Process

results.description:
When your architect is worth his weight in gold


Have you ever contemplated a project that was a toss up between a tear-down and and rehab?  Or one that you thought adding a second level would be the way to go?  Did you wonder if this was one of those times that “you don’t know what you don’t know”?

Graham Ruggie is the owner and principal architect of Janez Design, and earned a Master of Architecture degree from the Boston Architectural College, and a degree in management from Boston University.

You will hear:

·  When an architect can actually save you money, and when it doesn’t make sense to engage


·  Stock plans from the internet:  Pros and cons

·  Determining when you need an architect vs a structural engineer

·  Unique challenges of multi-family of 3+ and mixed use vs 1-2 family properties

·  Case studies including

• a gut renovation of a Lexington Cape converting to a Colonial

• unique houses with wetlands and terrain considerations

• a 4 unit mixed use requiring existing conditions assessment and impact to the code requirements

That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.

results.description:
Hey all,

Summer is drawing to a close again. The Sox have been playing at a level that means I don't feel particularly bad about not watching them, the Pats are in first place and kids are going back to school. Weather is still with us though, and if you're like me; and I know I am, you love the Boston skyline at night. So how about a Charles River run to go take it all in?

Planning on being at the Magazine Beach Park launch at 6ish for a (BIB) butts-in-boats time of 6:30pm. Sunset is 6:58pm, so I want to make sure we're out on the river to see it as we paddle along to the Esplanade through the lagoon. We'll pass the Hatch Shell and the sailing marina on our way to take a gander of the Zakim Bridge and the Charles River Dam. There probably isn't a paddler among us who hasn't driven across the bridge or has at least seen it at night. You're gonna love the view up at it from your kayak.
Onward we'll go sneaking through North Point Park, back around the horn in front of the Museum of Science to the Galleria and then we do a lazy paddle upstream on the northern bank of the river. By this time, Boston should be fully lit and spread out for our viewing pleasure on the port side all the way back to the landing.

This is a level 1 paddle - river will be calm and protected. Open to all boats - must be able to paddle in a group and keep pace - expected pace ~3 knots for 3 hours. Planned distance ~7 miles. PFD are required to be correctly worn. Night paddle - A suitable all round light required. Glow sticks on boat and PFD are acceptable. Headlamps or flashlights are recommended for as-needed use in navigation and landing.

I am not aware of any bathrooms available at the launch, but there are some available in the Esplanade. When you approach the park, go past the main entrance and use the ball field entrance. There you will find the ample parking and the ramp. Here is a link to the launch site from paddling.net:


http://www.paddling.net/launches/showLaunch.html?lid=16267
results.name: Sunset Paddle on the Charles River

results.description:
We have a new name, and a new run night for the new season! Formerly Team LUNA Chix Boston Run, we are now She Runs Boston! We meet every Tuesday at Athleta (92 Newbury Street) and will offer a 3 and a 4 mile loop around the esplanade. We have a no-drop policy, and welcome women of all paces and abilities, so you never have to worry about getting left behind. The staff at Athleta will securely hold your belongings for the duration of the run. We will try to start promptly at 6:30pm, so please arrive a few minutes early so that you can sign a waiver and introduce yourself to the group.

One more thing! We will have a post-run social on the last Tuesday of every month at a local bar. Everyone knows that you need to replace the carbs after a good run, right? Right!
results.name: run around the esplanade

results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog

results.description:
Boston / Cambridge SEO Internet Marketing Networking Group

The Cambridge SEO Meetup group is back this fall. From our humble beginnings at the Arlington Panera, we've now hosted over a 100 events featuring talks from some of the biggest names in internet marketing.

We invite  search, social, and affiliate marketing professionals in New England area or anyone looking to build their business or get more customers online to join us for networking and information sharing.

Location:

Bing / Microsoft Building

1 Memorial Dr

Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Cambridge, MA 02142

*** Bring a government-issued, photo ID. You will not be allowed in the Microsoft building without proper ID.

Agenda:

6:30pm to 7pm: Open Networking

Business Card Buffet: drop you card on the networking buffet

Food Sponsor

7pm to 7:30: 1 Min or less Elevator Pitch / Business Card Match Up

* Tell us about you and your business or website interest 
* Any networking goal your trying to achieve out of this meeting?

Then we exchange business cards on the spot to find you a match!

7:30-8:00

Guest Speaker - Roger Montti of Martinibuster.com

Classic SEO versus User Experience. 


User Experience as SEO is one of the most important developments in online marketing because it calls into question "classic" online marketing practices such as starting with a list of keywords then developing the page structure around that. Sites like those operated by Demand Media have experienced significant declines in my opinion largely because of keyword strategies that ignored the user experience.

8:00 - 8:30 Open Internet Marketing Q & A

We open the Q&A and discussion to possibly expand on other topics beyond the presentation.

8:30 to 8:45 Open Challenge Questions

Time to get advice to help fellow internet marketers.

8:45pm The End

We look forward to seeing you all at this informal Boston search engine round table discussion!

---------------------------------- 
Guest Speakers Wanted in Person or Google Hangout for virtual chats:

We've been working hard to find industry experts and to develop a formal agenda to keep it interesting for all those that attend.

https://www.berklee.edu/events/bitr-tuesday-featuring-annika-wells-caden-gray-tori-leche-trevor-dering-and-samuel-marks

BITR: Berklee in the RoundTuesday / September 15, 2015 / 7:00 p.m.

Red Room at Cafe 939

939 Boylston Street, Boston, Massachusetts, 02115, United States 

 (view map)

Berklee in the Round (BITR) occurs on the second Tuesday of every month. Each month a different faculty member selects four to five students and one special guest (a visiting artist, touring songwriter, or other performer) if possible, and hosts a concert. The event, based on in-the-round performances at the famous Bluebird Cafe in Nashville, Tennessee, seats songwriters in a circle where they take turns playing their songs with the audience seated around the performers, lending a more intimate feel to the show. 

This month's show will feature Annika Wells, Caden Gray, Tori Leche, Trevor Dering, and Samuel Marks, and will be hosted by Bonnie Hayes, chair of the Songwriting Department.

If you're interested in playing at BITR, you may submit two mp3's and the corresponding lyric sheets to the Songwriting faculty member who is hosting the night you want to play, or to [masked]. For information on who's playing, visit the BITR Facebook page. 

Admission: 

Free

http://www.meetup.com/Free-And-Cheap-Things-in-Boston/events/225362470/

http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Music-Jam/events/225362996/


PPS - The next BITR may be on October 12th, but stay tuned!

results.description:
This is a 4 week course. If you RSVP for this date you are RSVPing for the complete 4 week course (Tuesday evenings beginning September 15 through October 6. Please only RSVP if you are committed to attending to the whole series.


This course introduces students to the basic principles of 3D modeling, such as how to navigate in 3D space, what 3D models are made out of, and how to create simple forms and objects. The software used will be Sketchup, a free program that is excellent for beginners and professionals alike. Students will learn the ins and outs of the program, from basic techniques to advanced modeling concepts. This series is for people who have not already taken a 3D modeling class at HATCH.


Requirements:


• A free copy of Sketchup. 

• A CAD-capable laptop or desktop. The computer must have a discrete graphics chip or a very new (last three years) onboard graphics chip.


• A three button (minimum) mouse.


• You must be an experienced Windows or Mac user.


• You should be able to utilize keyboard shortcuts and understand how to use computer file systems.


*If you need a laptop please contact the organizer, we have six laptops available for use. We prefer that you use your own for this class.*

If you are bringing your own computer, please pre-load Sketchup Make. You can download it from www.sketchup.com.
results.how_to_find_us: We're located in the Arsenal Project (formerly Arsenal Mall). Park in the lot near Old Navy entrance, you'll see a big yellow-green sign over the doors. HATCH is between Pearle Vision and Game Stop.
results.name: Introduction to 3D Modeling (4 week class)

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
Click on this link to register http://newdharmayoga.com/travel/boston/

SAT SHREE ON THE EAST COAST

SEPT. 11-16, 2015

“The state of revelation is when the universe opens up for just a moment giving us a glimpse of the inherent Truth of existence.”


~Sat Shree

See Sat Shree’s Interview on Buddha at the Gas Pump

batgap.com/sat-shree

What happens when a successful architect and community activist in 1988, in a moment of despondency and alienation, collapses onto his drafting table—and wakes up hours later with Ecstatic energy coursing through every cell in his body? What then? Because an awakening is only the beginning of the spiritual journey, not the end. And when, as in Sat Shree’s case, there had been no preparation, no spiritual questing or even desire for a more spiritual life, this kind of rude, “kundalini” awakening can be easily mistaken for enlightenment. 

Somehow he knew it was a temporary state and therefore not the final answer. And so his journey began, leading away from his middle class life in Nevada, to a meeting with a teacher far ahead of him on the path, to years in an ashram in India, through increasingly ecstatic—and equally challenging —meditative experiences, through four distinct stages of enlightenment, and back to the United States. He is now the director of his New Dharma community in Nevada, where the force that is at work within him is shifting the reality of people that are drawn to it.

Sat Shree’s mission is to manifest a new spiritual culture that is in alignment with universal spiritual principles, and by doing so inspire mankind to create a sustainable future. “My work,” he says, “is to show people how to collaborate with the natural maturation process that occurs when one is on the spiritual path. A process that, in fact, all of mankind is going through.” 

This is Sat Shree’s first visit to the East Coast, made at the request of some of his students here on the shoreline. We hope you can join us. 

For more information about Sat Shree and the New Dharma community, visit newdharmayoga.org

CONNECTICUT SATSANG

Friday, Sept. 11, 7:00-8:30 pmMercy by the Sea, 167 Neck Road, Madison, CTAn interactive exploration into the nature of the new consciousness that is descending to the planet and how you can integrate it into daily life.

CONNECTICUT INTENSIVE

Saturday, Sept. 12, 11:00 am-5:00 pmMercy by the Sea, 167 Neck Road, Madison, CT

An opportunity to participate with Sat Shree and other attendees in silent sitting and self-inquiry into specifics of the various phases of the spiritual path, and what it means to live a divine life.

EARLY REGISTRATION DISCOUNTS

Register by Sept. 10 at newdharma-conn-events.eventzilla.net for early discounts.

FRIDAY SATSANG: $20 online by Sept 10; $25 at the door 

SATURDAY INTENSIVE: $90 online by Sept 10; $100 at the door 

BOTH EVENTS: $100 online by Sept 10; $125 at the door

BOSTON SATSANGS

Tues, Sept.15 & Wed, Sept. 16, 7:00 - 8:30

Newton, MA (30 participant maximum)

An interactive exploration into the nature of the new consciousness that is descending to the planet and how you can integrate it into daily life. 

$15 registered online at boston-satsangs0915.eventzilla.net

PRIVATE MEETINGS

Sat Shree will be holding private meetings with participants during the weekend in Connecticut and in Boston on Wednesday between 4pm and 6pm. Schedule a Skype Call on the New Dharma website prior to your visit with Sat Shree or request a personal meeting. There will only be 5 private meetings available so we encourage you to request a Skype meeting in lieu of a private meeting. If you receive a Skype meeting, please do not request a personal meeting.

QUESTIONS? For Connecticut events contact Karen Kernan,[masked] or [masked]. For Boston events contact Laura 

Katleman, [masked] or go to newdharmayoga.org.
results.name: Gathering with Sat Shree

results.description:
"Why Do Most People Believe in a Divine Being(s)?  How Do They Think They Benefit From Their Belief?"

Buzzy Jackson wrote about "wise words on the wonder and meaning of life" from the Atheist point of view in her book, "The Inspirational Atheist".

Atheism makes rational sense to most of us Humanists.  It removes some sources of guilt for some of us.  We sense some personal benefit.

But most people believe in a divine being.  They must derive some personal benefit or they would stop believing.

We will discuss what we think that benefit might be.


General Information

We meet on the third Tuesday in the Trustees Room of the Concord Public Library. We usually have eight to a dozen people attend to discuss the month's topic in a smaller setting and to get to know one another better.

Note that we have a large mailing list outside of Meetup.com and several regulars, so the RSVPs listed here will not reflect the actual attendance.
results.how_to_find_us: The Trustees Room is across the room to your right if you enter the main doors of the library (the ones that face downtown).
results.name: CAH Small Group Discussion ~ Benefits of Belief

results.description:
This Reiki Share is for you if you have been attuned as a Reiki Practitioner it is a powerful group Reiki session for all level Reiki Practitioners. A safe, supportive, nurturing and positive space is created for us to develop, practice and give back Reiki with like-minded friends. It is a great time to give yourself a tune-up and relish in Reiki.  Each practitioner will have the opportunity to give and receive Reiki during this relaxation and rejuvenating Reiki Share. Contact me if you have questions.

  Reiki Share Agenda

• The 1st 15 minutes of each share we will have time to connect with friends and introduce new members, allowing time to center and prepare for our Reiki sessions.

• It is our goal that each practitioner will have the opportunity to relish in 20 to 30 minutes of Reiki; dependent on how many practitioners are present for the share. 

• We will make every effort to synchronize each session allowing for the highest healing good of each person.

• Quiet discussion of the sessions may be shared quietly while your group is preparing for the next person.

• The room will be available at the conclusion of the Reiki Share so that you can socialize, give feedback and network with like-minded friends.

  Reiki Share Guidelines

• RSVP so that we may plan for adequate space and tables.

• Arrive on time, this allows time to center and enjoy the evening in a stress free manner.

• Please silence or turn off cell/mobile phones.

• During the share please be respectful of other groups enjoying Reiki by keeping conversations to a whisper and as brief as possible.  There will be ample time at the end of the evening for comments and discussions.

• If arriving late to the share, please enter the room "quietly" so the active session is not disturbed.  You may spend time in quite mediation, preparing for Reiki or enjoying self Reiki joining a group when the monument presents itself.  

Donations will be collected to offset the cost of the room.

results.description:
The IEEE has updated and added significant content to its IEEE-730 standard on Software Quality Assurance (SQA). The new version, which updates the previous version of 2002, describes three process areas and sixteen SQA tasks within these areas providing detailed elaborations for these areas and tasks. It also provides an overview of the key concepts of SQA, including its relation to product requirements, the relationship between project and organizational quality management, the relationship between supplier and acquirer (customer), and the overall flow of product and process requirements.

Speaker David Heimann will provide a "guided tour" of the new standard and the way it maps out SQA. We will also cover the annexes in IEEE 730 that provide more details about SQA planning, IEEE 730's relationship to the Agile development approach, industry-specific information, and relationships with software process approaches such as CMMI, SPICE, software product risk, and VSE (Very Small Enterprises).

Pizza and refreshments at 6pm.  Presentation begins at 7pm.
results.how_to_find_us: Please visit http://boston-spin.org for directions.  We will be meeting this month in Building S.
results.name: A Guide to the Greatly Updated IEEE 730 Software Quality Assurance Standard

results.description:
It's a lot easier to uncover our mental health, when our physical health is in good order. That is, when our body is fit and we're feeding it nutritious food. But that's often a lot easier said than done. What if you could get your body fit and healthy without the use of willpower? How would that change your life?

Join us at this Tuesday evening MeetUp to discuss how you can do just that! Jill Whalen will lead the discussion based on what she's learned and put into practice for herself over the past few years during her physical and emotional transformational journey. We'll have plenty of time for everyone to ask questions as well as provide their own transformative stories.
