results.description:
Presented by: Arlington Film Festival

Co-Sponsored by: Emerson College, MIRA, and FWD.us

Don’t Tell Anyone (No Le Digas a Nadie) is a film about courage, facing insurmountable obstacles and the determination to fight for justice.  In an environment where silence is often seen as necessary for survival, 24 year-old Angy Rivera steps out of the shadows to share her parallel journey of being undocumented and sexually abused, an ordeal all too common in her community. We follow Angy’s personal story from poverty in rural Colombia to the front page of The New York Times as she becomes a beacon in a movement for national change. Along her journey Angy inspires her undocumented mother Maria to speak openly about her status as well. Through verite footage and candid interviews, we witness firsthand the all too real consequences faced by over 11 million undocumented people in America today, many of whom have no options for a pathway to citizenship.
results.name: No Le Digas Film Screening

results.description:
Can You Understand Me Now?


Human Languages as Efficient Communication Systems, with MIT's Richard Futrell


Tuesday, September 15 from 7-8pm | Le Laboratoire Cambridge


Human languages have many properties that seem surprising from the perspective of communication: they are ambiguous, redundant, and apparently arbitrary. Richard Futrell, a PhD student in Cognitive Science at MIT, will discuss the remarkable variations among languages: some languages require you to mark gender all the time; in other languages never. In some languages you can rearrange words in whatever order you like, whereas in others such as English, you can’t. Surprisingly, many of the universal properties of languages and the range of arrangements in particular languages can be predicted by assuming that languages are efficient and robust communication systems. Futrell explains how this recent line of research works, and what it can tell us about language and the human mind. Do You Plan to Attend? Please join us for drink and conversation.


This is a free event, but limited seating is available.


We encourage you to you RSVP through Eventbrite:

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/can-you-understand-me-now-human-languages-as-efficient-communication-systems-with-mits-richard-tickets-18455728581


Directions to Le Laboratoire Cambridge, 650 East Kendall Street Public Transit: Red line to Kendall Square, walk straight down 3rd Street, turn right onto Athenaeum Street, and left onto East Kendall Parking: There is a parking deck - the 650 East Kendall Street Garage - accessible by Linskey Way.
If you purchase food or drink from Le Lab, your parking ticket can be validated for discounted rates.

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Inside our subconscious lie our memories from past lives. Though we seldom remember even having lived these past lives, the experiences we had living them have had a hand in shaping who we are today. The effects of a past life can manifest in a later lifetime in many ways - phobias, self-limiting beliefs, physical problems, or innate creative abilities. Violence, death, and trauma in a past life may show up as fear, uncontrollable anger, or low self-esteem in this one, while positive experiences from an earlier lifetime may cause you to feel strongly drawn to certain people, places, or objects without knowing why.

The subject of past lives and the possibility that we may have lived before has fascinated the public and perplexed researchers for generations. The fact is that there are thousands of past-life memories accumulating in the files of therapists worldwide, often mirroring unaccountable symptoms clients report, such as depression, anxiety, and feelings of loss and isolation - symptoms that seem to come out of nowhere, and can be difficult to treat. Could past-life memories offer us a key to unlocking these present-day psychological disturbances.

Past Life Regression, as practiced by Susan DameGreene is known as Deep Memory Process© - a practical and highly effective therapy of the soul, which combines active imagination (Jung), body work (Reich), and psychodrama (Moreno) with shamanic/spirit journeying and integration between lifetimes derived from the Tibetan Book of the Dead. 

Susan DameGreene has studied Past Life Regression since 1989 with Roger Woolger, a Jungian Analyst as well as an Oxford trained Psychotherapist who developed this groundbreaking method which is called Deep Memory Process© over his lifetime.She has  completed a 4 module program of coursework in England to be certified as a Deep Memory Process© Practitioner.

There is no charge for this meetup but registration is required by 6:30PM on the 15th.
results.name: Exploring Past Life Regression with Susan DameGreen FREE EVENT!b

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Wednesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
We are hosting our very first HackerLab event in Boston, MA! This is a four-hour, hands-on, strategically guided lab for developers that will cover how to build map apps with ArcGIS Online, APIs and Services, Open Source, and also with AppStudio for ArcGIS (for native apps). 

The tutorials are going to be led by Jim Barry and Nick Furness, who are really smart dudes that tends to focus on JavaScript. He will give you time to play in between the tutorials. Snacks will be there for you to munch on. This is a BYOM, BYOI, BYOA, and BYOD event: bring your own machine (seriously, we don't have any extras), ideas, apps and data. Yeah. 

Oh and here is a list of the required materials:

1. Computer

2. GitHub account

3. Git installed and configured 4. Text editor

5. ArcGIS for Developers or ArcGIS Organization account

HackerLab Agenda:

12:30PM - 5:00PM - HackerLab (We get started promptly at 12:30!)

WE REPEAT: Bring your own machine! We will not have any extras for use.

NOTE: There is also a GeoDev Meetup happening right after at 5:30PM and everyone is welcome to stay. RSVP to the meetup here: http://www.meetup.com/DevMeetUpNortheast/events/224728289/
results.name: Esri HackerLab - Boston, MA

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share'
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 
TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

Vegan Cooking Classes or  
Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food
(using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 


What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag? Portion Control Bake...Don't Fry! Roasted Veggie Stackers No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream Avocados!!! Salad with Chipotle Hummus Simple Cilantro Chutney More $2 bags of Produce! Drink your greens!

results.description:
An Esri GeoDev Meetup is taking place September 16th, where food and beverages will be provided! (Come a lil' hungry, why don't ya?)

This event is a social gathering for developers to discuss the latest in mapping, geo technology, geo services, web and mobile mapping apps, app design, cloud solutions, map data or anything else related to solving real-world "geo" problems.

Developers of all levels of expertise are welcome, from seasoned GIS professionals to those new to geospatial development. 

At these meet ups, you can: 

• Meet cool people. Duh, we're there.

• Show us what you got by demo'ing your application or framework.

• Make a name for yourself in presenting an cool new/interesting concept or idea.

• Impress someone by sharing your experiences.

• If you're sharp with your GIS and developer trivia, you can win some cool Esri swag 

• Make BFFs for life - connect with other developers! 

Here's what's on the agenda: 

5:30 - 6:30 PM Registration and Social (Appetizers and Beverages served - YES!) 

6:30 - 7:00 PM Introduction

7:00 - 8:00 Lightning talks

• Jonathan Hall, "Mt. Washington Avalanche Center's Daily Advisory and the National Avalanche Map"


• Calvin Metcalf, "The 5 Implementations of WMS/WMTS of QGIS and ArcMap in 15 Slides"


• Sal Shahini, "PAVEMON: A Data Driven GIS Online PAVEment MONitoring System"


8:00 - 8:30 PM Raffle, Networking and Social. Two great (no, FANTASTIC) prizes: 

A voucher for 1000 Service Credits for your ArcGIS Online Developer Subscription

A free registration pass to attend the 2016 Esri DevSummit

Be sure to follow us on Twitter #geodev @AmyNiessen, @geeknixta, and @JimBarry.
results.name: GeoDev Meetup - Boston, MA

results.description:
Hi All!
A number of you have shown interest in a weekday evening meetup in the downtown Boston area. Here it is! Please come and join us for a casual 2 hours ASL social on Wednesdays from 5:30 to 7:30 pm.


WHO: All who are interested in ASL are welcome to join us. Whether you're Deaf or hearing, beginner or fluent ASL user, we're here to share and socialize in this beautiful language.

WHERE: We'll be in the City Place Food Court in Dept of Transportation Building (use entrance on Boylston Street across street from Boylston Street T stop or entrance on Stuart Street) . Since we'll most likely be the only group of people signing, we should be pretty easy to spot.

RULES: Voices off, use paper and pen if you need to--this helps us learn and its Deaf friendly


RESOURCES: For those of you who are new to ASL and want to come prepared, here are some very good websites with free online classes.

http://www.westwoodasl.com/ http://www.lifeprint.com/ http://www.start-american-sign-language.com/

RSVP: Please RSVP for the meetup that you will be attending so we know how many people to expect.

CONTACT: Please feel free to contact host (Sean) if you have any questions or concerns. Hope to see you there! :)
results.how_to_find_us: Look for people signing!
results.name: Downtown Boston Weekly ASL Social

Otherwise just bring the ability to forgive the robber for stealing your sheep.

The ability to overlook how the other Munchkin players have stopped you from getting past level 9 ten times in a row and suddenly your down to level 8. Just breath, in and out, in and out.

Recent lesson learned: Never pull a ticket for NY to LA when another player only has 8 trains left. Keep those eyes open.

results.description:
ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: Now in its 12th year, the weekly Boston Poetry workshop (formerly “Charles River Writers”) has always been an open forum for literary fellowship and discussion. 

To participate, please RSVP here, and arrive bearing enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss – whether prose or verse – for each participant to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies of your writing, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! Likewise let us know if you’d like to suggest a writing exercise or event.
results.name: Weekly Writing Workshop

results.description:
Title: Think small

Abstract:

Many "big data" and evidently computationally expensive problems can be easier to solve than they seem. Because, often, information << data, something Michael Wu calls "the big data fallacy". We examine some real-world examples from network analysis, finance and genomics and show that sometimes simple tools like R and a laptop can be as good at solving problems as big complicated distributed computing systems like Spark or Hadoop.

Speaker:  Bryan W. Lewis
results.how_to_find_us: http://www.meetup.com/Boston-useR/
results.name: Come "Think small" with our frequent guest speaker Bryan Lewis

results.description:
Long-short equity strategies are an incredibly robust family of strategies. They depend on a methodology to rank equities, and perform proportionally to how well the ranking system differentiates high and low future returns. They avoid many forms of statistical bias and noise, and are an excellent way to make money off a model that predicts future returns for any given asset. 

This lecture will go over the background and implementation of a long-short equity strategy on Quantopian. 

This talk is part of Quantopian’s Summer Lecture Series. All lecture materials can be found at:  www.quantopian.com/lectures.

Pizza and beverages will be provided by Quantopian.

Speaker Details:

Delaney Granizo-Mackenzie is an engineer at Quantopian whose focus is on how Quantopian can be used as a teaching tool. After studying computer science at Princeton, Delaney joined Quantopian in 2014. Since then he has led successful course integrations at MIT Sloan and Stanford, and is working with over 20 courses for this fall. Delaney is using his experience and feedback from professors to build a quantitative finance curriculum focusing on best statistical practices to be offered for free. Delaney’s background includes 7 years of academic research at a bioinformatics lab, and a strong focus on statistics and machine learning.
results.how_to_find_us: Entrance is on Arch Street. We are on the 5th floor.
results.name: Quantopian Lecture: How to Build a Long-Short Equity Strategy

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Hello Everyone! We are thrilled to announce that Docker Boston will host Docker Global Hack Day #3!

AGENDA

6:00 Arrival

6:30 Form teams and start hacking

7:30 Break for presentations by the Docker Team via Livestream/Dinner and Beverages served

8:30 Continue hacking!

10:00 Event ends - hacking remotely continues throughout the week and weekend until Monday, September 21, 9:00 AM PDT!!

Rules:

As a team of 1-3 hackers, you will hack on a project using Docker as the central piece. You will have exactly from 4pm PDT on Wednesday, September 16th to 9am PDT on Monday, September 21st to complete this project. This window includes the time to create all materials needed for your submission.

Although it is not allowed to start your project before 4pm PDT on Wednesday, September 16th, we strongly encourage everyone to think about project ideas in advance. We will build a page with all the project ideas for everyone to see what ideas have already been submitted and help participants form teams.

Everyone will submit projects in one of three categories listed below:

1) Docker Plugins 
2) Docker Plumbing – runC, Notary, etc 
3) Docker Freestyle – must use features from Docker 1.8 and above (including experimental binaries). 

Submit Your Hack Ideas:

You will be able to submit through this form until Thursday, September 17th at 9am PDT with:

• Hack Title 
• Brief abstract [masked] word description) 
• Hacker Name 
• Best way to contact project lead 
• URL describing the project idea 
• How can other people help you?

The Docker community will then vote on the best hack in each category in two different ways.

Winners:

1) Local Docker Meetup winners 

A jury composed of Docker Engine core maintainers will vote for the local edition winners from each Meetup group that organized a local edition of the Docker Global Hack Day.

Prizes for the local edition winners will be announced soon.

2) Global Docker Global Hack Day Winners

We will build a page with all projects and videos for the community to vote for the global winner. Note that Local Docker Meetup winners will be featured on this page.

Voting will be done through social networks – stay tuned for an update on how this voting will work.

The Global winning team will be invited to attend DockerCon Europe (conference tickets + accommodations for each member of the winning team).

</a>

<a href="http://europe.dockercon.com/">

</a>

<a href="http://europe.dockercon.com/">

</a>

<a href="http://europe.dockercon.com/">

</a>

<a href="http://europe.dockercon.com/">

</a>

<a href="http://europe.dockercon.com/">

Connect with the Docker hackers from around the world!

During the day the Docker team and the Docker community will be on IRC helping you hack your project or answering questions about Docker. The official back channel for this event on IRC is #docker.

The official hashtag for the event on Twitter is #dockerhackday. Everybody can tweet using this hashtag. You can also follow us on Twitter to receive news real-time during the day.

About Akamai

Akamai helps businesses connect the hyperconnected, empowering them to transform and reinvent their business online. We remove the complexities of technology, so you can focus on driving your business faster forward. Enabling you to embrace trends like mobile and cloud, while overcoming the challenges presented by security threats and the need to reach users globally. Read More

About Docker 

Docker is an open platform for developers and sysadmins to build, ship, and run distributed applications. Consisting of Docker Engine, a portable, lightweight runtime and packaging tool, and Docker Hub, a cloud service for sharing applications and automating workflows, Docker enables apps to be quickly assembled from components and eliminates the friction between development, QA, and production environments. Read more

results.description:
This is an information-rich workshop on home buying presented by an experienced home buyer, investor, and former agent. The workshop is a community service of ePlace, a real estate firm in Cambridge.

Topics will include: * deciding on the price point that is right for you * understanding mortgages, mortgage expenses, and getting pre-approved * finding a home * property due diligence and comparative market analysis * elements of the offer * home inspection, purchase and sale, mortgage contingency, walk-through and closing * special discussion of how to get a property in a tight market and paths to affordable homeownership. We'll also review all of the forms involved in purchasing a property in Massachusetts. 

Feel free to email [masked] with any questions, or read what people are saying about the Savvy Home Buyer.

results.description:
I may be a little late as I'll be coming from getting my hair colored... keeping the grey away is # priority. ...

One more time... no rain in the forecast...

Lets check out the new Boston Public Market... the brand new permanent, year-round, self-sustaining market featuring fresh, locally sourced food brought directly to and from the diverse people that make up MA and NE. At the Boston Public Market, farmers, fishermen, and food producers from MA and NE offer the public a year-round source of fresh, local food and an opportunity to taste, buy, and understand what our region has to offer. The market houses over 35 vendors selling locally produced items such as farm-fresh produce, meat/poultry, eggs, milk, cheese, fish, bread, baked goods, flowers, and an assortment of specialty and prepared food. I went this past weekend and found wheel barrels filled with sunflowers, beautifully displayed items, and delicious food.

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.
results.how_to_find_us: The folks talking with their hands!
results.name: Weekly North Shore ASL Social!

Want to know what it's like working on a day to day basis with Ocean City Development? Here's your chance.


We will be featuring Andrew Chapman of Cameron Real Estate Group. Andrew has been an agent for 8 years and has had experience working at both a smaller niche real estate office and a larger franchise run office. He officially joined our Team in November as an agent and has been working our leads ever since.

On the call, we'll be discussing:

1. Life before Ocean City Including:

a. Day to Day Schedule

b. Number of leads his previous brokerages provided him

c. Number of appointments per week he was averaging prior to joining

d. Number of deals closed per year(on average)

e. The hesitations that he had prior to joining us

And


2. Life With Ocean City Including:

a. What his day to day schedule looks like now

b. The number of leads per week that we supply him with

c. The number of appointments per week that he averages now that he is with us

d. Volume of deals he has closed since the transition

e. The answer to the question of whether his intiial hesitation about joining us had any validity

This webinar is meant to be an inside look behind the walls of Ocean City and is presented in order to give viewers an unbiased look at both the positives and the negatives of our company from a 3rd party perspective.

results.description:
WE ARE BACK IN DAVIS SQUARE FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

Join us for a FREE Introduction to ‘Eat to Thrive’

on

Wed. Sept. 16, 2015 
6:30 – 8:30 PM

¨  FREE Smoothie Demo with Samples

¨ Receive a $50 discount when signing up for the 10-week Life Transforming Class at this event!

Location: 
Arlington Senior Center Art Room 
27 Maple Street 
Arlington, MA 02476

Accessible by public transportation

Hear the Success Stories of ‘Eat to Thrive’ Graduates:

Alan Krentzel   

“With the scary diagnosis of stage 4 aggressive cancer, I researched for the best fuel to put in my tank and discovered ‘Eat to Thrive’.”

Randy Jacobs

“The class has enabled me to understand how my body functions and what it needs to make it apart of my everyday life.”

Heike Westphal 

“Eat to Thrive Jan ’13, Oct ’13 & Oct ‘ 14 ‘ reinforced what I’ve learned at HHI and connected me to like-minded people.”

Brian Axelrod 

“Optimum Health’s ‘Eat to Thrive’ course got me back on my raw feet and feeling inspired to educate, and change the current American eating paradigm.”

Tom Bertulis 

“Raw vegan food and the LFE class have transformed me. I have more energy, a happy glow, and it’s helped my workouts at the climbing gym and my athletic performance as a runner.  With the recipes I’ve learned at LFE, it’s easy to go raw!”

Lupe Ojeda 

“After taking ‘Eat to Thrive’ Levels 1, 2, and 3, my 11-year-old son and I are no longer diabetic or anemic.”

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

America is facing an epidemic of diabetes, cancer, obesity, malnutrition and heart disease. Research shows that many of today’s chronic diseases are completely tied to what we eat and the lifestyle choices we make. According to the Centers for Disease Control, obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. 

The Real Kids Real Food (RKRF) after-school program for inner-city kidsprovides a solution to this epidemic - one child at a time!  Together, with your help, we can change these statistics.

Real Kids Real Food (RKRF) is changing children’s lives through hands-on preparation of real nutritious meals (probably the healthiest they will eat all week).  RKRF incorporates not only food, but an exercise program to help prevent obesity, chronic disease and malnutrition.  RKRF was created by Optimum Health Solution (501c3), a non-profit organization which provides education and advocacy of healthy living.

Real Kids Real Food (RKRF) children learn the importance of organic and local foods and the true value of a meal with its full life force as intended by nature. They are encouraged to read labels of processed foods and to make better choices of unprocessed and raw foods to nourish their bodies with adequate fiber and natural enzymes. Parents are also educated as part of this program. One of the parents of RKRF, trained by our organization, is launching Familia Saludable for Spanish-speaking parents. Our larger goal is to encourage change in their lifestyles by building better habits such as reading, exercise, self-care and gardening, which will enable them to love fresh foods. We are very excited to announce that an e-book is currently being created to offer RKRF in many more communities. 

http://www.OptimumHealthSolution.org

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Wednesday Magic In Medford

results.description:
Get in shape before the season!! The leader (Bob Barnes) of the Wedeln Ski and Snowboard Race Team will hold dryland training every Wednesday night this Fall. The workout is great for anyone who wants to get in shape, you do not have to be a skier or racer. Bob's enthusiasm for skiing and training is contagious, he will get you working hard and getting results. All fitness levels are welcome but come ready to sweat. Bob will lead the group in Plyometric based training methods designed to get the leg muscles ready for the season. This is the same workout that he has used for many years to prepare for the ski season.

There is no charge - we are just a bunch of skiers and riders trying to help each other get in shape. Darlene Stokes and Tom Lane will also lead the group in additional exercises designed to increase flexibility and build a strong core. Last year we had many people from Meetup join us for these workouts. Some even became regular guests up at our ski house in NH. Ski Fitness Training is a great way to get ready for the season and make some friends you can join on the slopes when the weather gets colder. The workouts last 1.5 hours and are always immediately followed by a few drinks and sometimes some food at a variety of Waltham Center Bars/Restaurants. Please wear work-out clothes and athletic shoes with some ankle support.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in the center of Waltham common near the flag poles.
results.name: Pre-season ski fitness training

I do feel we should reciprocate. So I am asking you to either join me at 6 for a bite to eat before Meetup or if that is not possible that you give a $5 donation which I will pass along to the Cafew'.

In the Meetup we will use a Wooden Pillow to massage pour feet, neck, shoulders lower back and abdomen. Experience the release of tension throughout the body and deep relaxation. The Wooden Pillow is a great healing tool. Useful for headaches, lower back pain, neck tension and abdominal bloating.

We will end with meditation.

Hope to see you there.

Barbara

Research shows that many of today’s chronic diseases are completely tied to what we eat and the lifestyle choices we make. According to the Centers for Disease Control, obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. 

The Real Kids Real Food (RKRF) after-school program for inner-city kidsprovides a solution to this epidemic - one child at a time!  Together, with your help, we can change these statistics.

Real Kids Real Food (RKRF) is changing children’s lives through hands-on preparation of real nutritious meals (probably the healthiest they will eat all week).  RKRF incorporates not only food, but an exercise program to help prevent obesity, chronic disease and malnutrition.  RKRF was created by Optimum Health Solution (501c3), a non-profit organization which provides education and advocacy of healthy living.

Real Kids Real Food (RKRF) children learn the importance of organic and local foods and the true value of a meal with its full life force as intended by nature. They are encouraged to read labels of processed foods and to make better choices of unprocessed and raw foods to nourish their bodies with adequate fiber and natural enzymes. Parents are also educated as part of this program. One of the parents of RKRF, trained by our organization, is launching Familia Saludable for Spanish-speaking parents. Our larger goal is to encourage change in their lifestyles by building better habits such as reading, exercise, self-care and gardening, which will enable them to love fresh foods. We are very excited to announce that an e-book is currently being created to offer RKRF in many more communities. 

http://www.OptimumHealthSolution.org

[masked]

[masked]
results.name: FREE Introduction to Eat to Thrive course: 10 weeks to Life Long Healthy Habits

I'm excited to announce our next meetup on web accessibility! The format for this one is a presentation and then a demo. Doors open at 6:30pm for food and drinks, which will be provided. The talk will start at 7pm. 

The Carroll Center for the Blind’s Accessibility Services team will share an overview of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG 2.0) and provide a live demonstration of Job Access with Speech (JAWS) screen reader software.

A bit about our presenters:


Bruce Howell (Accessibility Services Coordinator) -

Bruce Howell joined the staff at the Carroll Center for the Blind in July of 2012. He works with clients to identify and articulate their online accessibility needs, and assigns Carroll Center resources to best meet those client requirements. In his spare time Bruce is a competitive sailor with the SailBlind program out of the Courageous Sailing Center in Charlestown.

Jacqui Tolisano (Web Accessibility Specialist) -

Jacqui, an Art Institute of Pittsburgh, online division graduate with over 10 years of web content experience, joined the Carroll Center for the Blind in September, 2012. She quickly developed a passion for web accessibility and promoting awareness about equal access to online content.

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of twelve attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!
results.how_to_find_us: We usually meet on the lower level -- look for the games!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
From amazon.com

A lot of remarkable things have happened in the life of Sam Pulsifer, the hapless hero of this incendiary novel, beginning with the ten years he spent in prison for accidentally burning down Emily Dickinson's house and unwittingly killing two people. Emerging at age twenty-eight, he creates a new life and identity as a husband and father. But when the homes of other famous New England writers suddenly go up in smoke, he must prove his innocence by uncovering the identity of this literary-minded arsonist.

In the league of such contemporary classics as A Confederacy of Dunces and The World According to Garp, An Arsonist's Guide to Writers' Homes in New England is an utterly original story about truth and honesty, life and the imagination.

results.description:
For our September Maptime, Kent Johnson will teach us about mapping in R. We will walk through a simple example of loading GIS data into R and making a slippy map with leaflet.js. No JavaScript coding needed!

As always, beginners very welcome. Please bring a laptop. If you want to follow along, you should install a few things ahead of time:

• R - install the latest version for your platform from https://cran.rstudio.com/

• RStudio Desktop Open Source edition - latest from https://www.rstudio.com/products/RStudio/

• Data and code will be available on Github before the meeting.

Come hungry. There will be pizza courtesy of CartoDB again!

--------

Maptime is, rather literally, time for mapmaking. Our mission is to open the doors of cartographic possibility to anyone interested by creating a time and space for collaborative learning, exploration, and map creation using mapping tools and technologies.

This open learning environment for all levels and degrees of knowledge offers intentional support for the beginner. Maptime is simultaneously flexible and structured, creating space for workshops, ongoing projects with a shared goal, and independent/collaborative work time.

Inspiration for Maptime comes from both hack nights and knitting circles. Both are models of spaces for people to create and learn together. Our goal is to provide this space with an open heart and without pretension. You can bring your own projects to work on, or just hang out and socialize or ask questions. Some people are experts, and some people are just getting started, but all of us are learning, so why not do it together?

Maptime is hands-on, so don't forget to bring your pencil!
results.how_to_find_us: When you enter the building, check in with security - let them know you're attending Maptime on the 4th floor.
results.name: Mapping with R

Boston NOW's Feminist Book Club is our reading group for anybody who loves to read and identifies as a feminist. We'll be reading a variety of books that may fall into one of the following categories:

results.description:
Damon Tweedy discusses Black Man in a White Coat: A Doctor's Reflections on Race and Medicine

This event is free and includes a book signing; no tickets are required.

Wednesday, September 16th, 2015, 7pm

Harvard Book Store

1256 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge

Harvard Book Store welcomes physician DAMON TWEEDY for a discussion of his book Black Man in a White Coat: A Doctor's Reflections on Race and Medicine. 

Black Man in a White Coat is one doctor's passionate and profound memoir of his experience grappling with race, bias, and the unique health problems of black AmericansWhen Damon Tweedy begins medical school,he envisions a bright future where his segregated, working-class background will become largely irrelevant. Instead, he finds that he has joined a new world where race is front and center. The recipient of a scholarship designed to increase black student enrollment, Tweedy soon meets a professor who bluntly questions whether he belongs in medical school, a moment that crystallizes the challenges he will face throughout his career. Making matters worse, in lecture after lecture the common refrain for numerous diseases resounds, "More common in blacks than whites." 

Black Man in a White Coat examines the complex ways in which both black doctors and patients must navigate the difficult and often contradictory terrain of race and medicine. As Tweedy transforms from student to practicing physician, he discovers how often race influences his encounters with patients. Through their stories, he illustrates the complex social, cultural, and economic factors at the root of most health problems in the black community. These issues take on greater meaning when Tweedy is himself diagnosed with a chronic disease far more common among black people. In this powerful, moving, and deeply empathic book, Tweedy explores the challenges confronting black doctors, and the disproportionate health burdens faced by black patients, ultimately seeking a way forward to better treatment and more compassionate care.

Purchase the Book: Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases.

General Info: (617)[masked] - [masked] 

Media Inquiries: (617)[masked] x1 - [masked] 

Accessibility Inquiries: [masked]
results.name: Black Man / White Coat

results.description:
The Boston Austrian Economics Group will meet to discuss the economics of refugees. The reading is not required, all are welcome to attend.

READINGS

"Illegal Immigrants Are Bolstering Social Security With Billions"
http://nyti.ms/1KmyJ2Q

"Suffer Little Children"
http://nyti.ms/1yzOQBE

"Does Immigration Impact Economic Freedom?"
http://bit.ly/1jtnzhq

"Immigration and the Changing Nature of Homicide in US Cities"
http://bit.ly/1J8Az1W

STUDY QUESTIONS: THE ECONOMICS OF REFUGEES

1. In The Simpsons Movie, the US federal government put a giant plastic bubble around the town of Springfield. What commonly used state policies would have the same economic effect?

2. In Japan, people have very long life expectancies, the birth rate is very low, and very few immigrants are allowed. Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso recently said about the elderly: "The problem won't be solved unless you let them hurry up and die.” What problem is Aso talking about? Does the US face this problem? Why does the US face a less-extreme version of this problem than Japan?

3. In a free market, capital flows to its most profitable uses. When the state erects barriers to entry, capital is restricted from flowing to its most profitable uses. What are the economic consequences of restricting the movement of capital? How does this relate to immigration?

4. A recent voter initiative in Switzerland proposed giving every citizen $3,250 a month, which, even when adjusted for cost of living differences, would put every Swiss citizen in the top 1% of income earners worldwide. Could Switzerland open its borders with such a policy? Could Hong Kong keep its open borders and adopt such a policy? Do both the CATO study and Paul Krugman both agree that immigration correlates with a smaller welfare state? What does this say about the Cloward-Piven strategy, a strategy two sociologists proposed for turning the US into a welfare state through opening the borders?

5. When New York City tried to raise its city income tax to 4%, it received less tax revenue than when the tax was 2%. Why might this be? If NYC was a city state with immigration restrictions, could it get away with a higher tax rate?

6. When Georgia passed a tough anti-immigrant law in 2012, crops rotted in the fields in a scope not seen in decades since hardline communism fell. Why did supply and demand fail to match?

7. A study in the Journal of Quantitative Criminology reports that homicides negatively correlate with immigration in US cities, with the strongest effect being in cities with the highest number of immigrants. Why might this be? Why might this study be misleading?

8. A recent Pew survey found that 95% of Vietnamese citizens support capitalism over socialism, 76% of Chinese citizens do as well, while only 70% of Americans support this. Why might this be?

9. Besides border walls, what other migration barriers does the state erect? Do some of these barriers prevent Americans from moving inside America?

10. Why were immigration restrictions listed as a charge against the King in the Declaration of Independence? “He has endeavoured to prevent the population of these States; for that purpose obstructing the Laws for Naturalization of Foreigners; refusing to pass others to encourage their migrations hither, and raising the conditions of new Appropriations of Lands”
results.name: The Economics of Refugees

results.description:
Yo!! This was one of the books on the poll!  See how that works?  You guys suggest a dope ass book and the author comes to town.  The knowledge will be coming from the source.  I will be there in full effect!

Check out the information below:

http://www.harvard.com/event/damon_tweedy/


This event is free; no tickets are required.


Harvard Book Store welcomes physician DAMON TWEEDY for a discussion of his book Black Man in a White Coat: A Doctor's Reflections on Race and Medicine. This event is co-sponsored by Mass Humanities and the Hutchins Center for African and African American Research.

Black Man in a White Coat is one doctor's passionate and profound memoir of his experience grappling with race, bias, and the unique health problems of black Americans

When Damon Tweedy begins medical school,he envisions a bright future where his segregated, working-class background will become largely irrelevant. Instead, he finds that he has joined a new world where race is front and center. The recipient of a scholarship designed to increase black student enrollment, Tweedy soon meets a professor who bluntly questions whether he belongs in medical school, a moment that crystallizes the challenges he will face throughout his career. Making matters worse, in lecture after lecture the common refrain for numerous diseases resounds, "More common in blacks than whites."

Black Man in a White Coat examines the complex ways in which both black doctors and patients must navigate the difficult and often contradictory terrain of race and medicine. As Tweedy transforms from student to practicing physician, he discovers how often race influences his encounters with patients. Through their stories, he illustrates the complex social, cultural, and economic factors at the root of most health problems in the black community. These issues take on greater meaning when Tweedy is himself diagnosed with a chronic disease far more common among black people. In this powerful, moving, and deeply empathic book, Tweedy explores the challenges confronting black doctors, and the disproportionate health burdens faced by black patients, ultimately seeking a way forward to better treatment and more compassionate care.
results.name: Author's Talk:  Black Man in a White Coat by Damon Tweedy

Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

It is open to everyone. Starting times are 7:30pm during the fall and winter, and 8:30pm during the spring and summer. The program lasts about an hour.

Weather

The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here.

Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

>>> Tickets <<<

Public Open Nights are open to everyone, however space is limited. To reserve a ticket for admission click this link which will take you to our Eventbrite page.  [see website]

Location

The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Ave. in Boston, right above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell to the Observatory is on the fifth floor right next to room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.
Information

For information, please call[masked]-2630.

The Public Open Night at the Observatory is held clear Wednesday nights from 8:30 – 9:30pm. Call[masked] for the status.

Source: http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/
results.name: Public Open Night - Coit Observatory at Boston University

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
Tune in at http://artistfirst.com/arthurdschwartz.htm


This show will be be wide-ranging conversation between two persons who have an abiding passion for philosophy. I have discussed my passion for philosophy many times on this show and will continue to share it as this radio program evolves. My guest, Jeannie Connerney, is someone whose philosophic passion is as energetic as my own but in this conversation we will see how the divergent paths of philosophy are at the root of much of its appeal. In philosophy, the "one and the many" is a central concept, and philosophy is  itself a mirror reflection of this core concept. Philosophy has common themes about seeking truth and cogent reasoning in all areas but, within this commonality, there is enormous diversity of opinion.

Now, while I imagine, Jeannie and I may agree more than disagree, I am sure that points of divergence will make for a great conversation that will--I hope--shed some light on the nature of philosophy. Jeannie will talk a bit about her philosophical biography and we will compare some notes as starting points in our discussion of philosophical convergence and divergence. In the end, perhaps the idea of philosophy will become even just a little clearer. 

I'd like to share some "discussion starters" that Jeannie provided me with:

• How did you come to study philosophy?

• What type of philosophy and which philosophers were you drawn to early on, and did this change?

• Role of literature in coming to philosophy? Art? Politics?

• Was there a role that religion played in leading you to philosophy? What do you think about religion now?

• Valuable moments in philosophical education—classes, professors, books, papers. Influences.

• Who are the key philosophers in your life, and how did they influence you?Were there ideas that really excited you?

• Philosophy can lead one both to and away from conventional morality or ethics. How is this good or bad? 

• Do you end up knowing anything after studying philosophy? What is the value of philosophy, both individually and for society/culture?

• Discuss philosophical methods or methodology in general.

• Are there philosophers you don’t like or with whom you disagree? Why?I can't wait until Wednesday! 


******************


Your RSVP indicates that you plan on listening to the show. After listening to the broadcast or the subsequently posted podcast you will  be able to post comments on this page. (No, Cyberville MA is not a real place! But I look forward to "seeing" you on the radio, September 16, 2015, 10pm Eastern/7pm Pacific.)


Philosophic Perspectives with Arthur D. Schwartz. Visit the show page at: http://artistfirst.com/arthurdschwartz.htm
results.name: The Passions of Philosophy with Special Guest Jeannie Connerney

results.description:
Important - for this event you must register using this link. So the number of people who click Attending on Meetup does not represent the true number of people who have registered. The registration fee includes a full breakfast at the Riverbend restaurant.


On the third Thursday of (almost) every month SAMI hosts a breakfast discussion on a topic related to new directions in sales and marketing. This month's topic is on aligning sales and the buyer's education.


Over the last decade or two, for most organizations the sales process hasn’t changed much, however the buying process has changed dramatically. Clients are educating themselves well before engaging sales. Our ability to influence the sale is reduced and we need to rely on “blind” education in the evaluation stage. Our strategy and channels have to change to match the new behavior.  In this breakfast round table we will be discussing buyer concerns through their process and how sales people must adjust and educate differently, and how marketers can help produce the content for sales people to use.


.  Takeaways from the discussion will include:


•  When is the best time to “educate” or “re-educate” buyers

• What’s the value of a seller’s insights and expertise in the buying process?

• What are the roles of marketing and sales in educating buyers ?


Marie Warner will lead this discussion, drawing on her 9 years as a Chief Sales Officer, plus 15 years of consulting to large enterprises and startups helping to define and implement process in building and developing sales teams, and aligning B2B sales process with the buyer's journey.

Bring your thoughts and join the discussion!

Register here.

And look for updates on great SAMI free evening events to be added to this Meetup shortly.
results.how_to_find_us: We're in the Riverbend restaurant at the back of the first floor
results.name: Monthly breakfast discussion on sales and marketing

results.description:
Join us again this Thursday morning before you head out to work for a guided meditation of Scripture in the Jesuit tradition of Lectio Divina (Sacred Reading). All faiths (or non-faiths) are welcome! Alice will be facilitating.


What is Lectio?

Lectio Divina is an ancient Christian practice of unhurried, contemplative meditation on a portion of Scripture following four basic movements: 

Lectio: a time of slow repeated reading of Scripture punctuated by the use of a bell or chime. 

Meditatio: A time of quiet reflection on God's words and presence. 

Oratio: A time of silent conversational intimacy with God. 

Contemplatio: A time of listening for God's words for us personally.

We hope you'll join us in this deeply enriching spiritual practice.

results.name: Lectio Divina Meditation (Sacred Reading)

If you have a Scrabble board/set, please feel free to bring it with you. However, it is not required.
Also, look for people who have Scrabble sets/boards with them.

I'm greatly looking forward to seeing you there!

Best,
Lisa
results.name: Meet New Friends and Play Scrabble

results.description:
Dear Fashiontechs, I'm spreading the information of an event organized by Fashion 4WRD, and hope to meet some of you at the event.

Please REGISTER at this link: 

http://www.mitforumcambridge.org/events/fashion-4wrd-revealing-the-future-of-design-technology/

And...stay tuned with our events!


"""
We’re kicking off our[masked] program year in style!
Dress to impress and inspire for an interactive evening at the Museum of Fine Arts Boston that will explore the future of design, fashion, science and technology! We’re partnering with Descience and the MFA for this truly unique event which will begin with a panel discussion featuring designers, entrepreneurs, material futurists, and technologists re-envisioning how the global fashion industry will operate in the next 10 years.

Speakers
Suzanne Lee. Creative Director, Modern Meadow
Chris Wawrousek, Lead Designer, New Balance, Innovation Studio
Dr. Amanda Parkes, Fashion Technologist,Chief of Technology and Research, Manufacture New York

After the panel, mingle in our Future Fashion Lab with our sponsors and featured designers, engineers and entrepreneurs who represent the future of fashion. We’ll also provide a sneak peak at how the 3D printed jewelry on display at the MFA was created.

FASHION 4WRD aims to reveal the future of Fashion Design and Technology, BE PART and Apply here to be considered to show with companies, start ups and individuals shaping the future of fashion.

Please note: Ticket price does not include museum admission ($25) exceptions include MFA Members (free), University Students and more. See MFA Website for Admission details & discounts.

Event Schedule
5:30 PM – 6:00 PM – Registration
6:00 PM – 7:00 PM – Panel Discussion
7:00 PM – 9:00 PM – Future Fashion Lab & Networking Reception


This event is sponsored by Wolf Greenfield.
Wolf Greenfield

Non-member price: $95
New members can buy the full-price ticket below or become a member and receive discounts.

Member pricing
Student: $45
Tech-Entrepreneur: $45
Business-Professional: $45
results.name: Fashion 4WRD: Revealing the Future of Design & Technology

results.description:
Hi Ladies, this not a meetup. I have learned I am not her

Some of you know and others may not. I have been extremely busy over the past 6 weeks assisting my parents and finally all is settled,  lots of stuff going on and for now all is good  During this time I needed to put my Biscotti business on hold and have signed up to 2 craft fairs on Sat/Sun.  Thought I could do it on my own and learned tonight I need some help.

I actually assigned my parents to put ingredient labels on my packaging.  However, I still need to dip some more biscotti in chocolate and package them.

So, if I can ask if any of you have about 2 hours to spare, if you could stop by and be my biscotti elves. 

I just need 2 max 3 of you and I will provide pizza and beverages.

I don't like to ask for help, but also know not to be afraid to ask if you realize you just can't do it all.

Again, just need 2 max 3 and you know I will make it fun.
results.name: Biscotti Dippers & Packaging Helpers Needed

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
